headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gabrielle. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2015 third quarter earnings call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Frank Gibeau, our EVP of Mobile; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A po
componenttext:
Thank you, Gabrielle. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2015 third quarter earnings call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Frank Gibeau, our EVP of Mobile; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared reports. Lastly, after the call, we will post our prepared remarks an audio replay of this call and a transcript. A couple of Canada. We'll be presenting at the Nicholas in San Francisco on Monday, February 9; and the date of our next earnings report will be Tuesday, May 5. This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events or results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. Electronic Arts makes these statements as of today, January 27, 2015, and disclaims any duty to update them. 
During this call, unless otherwise noted, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our adapter non-GAAP measures. These are non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, as a substitute for, or superior to our GAAP results. We encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year, unless otherwise stated. Now I will turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Q3 was an outstanding quarter for Electronic Arts. Dragon Age: Inquisition was named to more than 200 game of the year globally. More than 6 million people on average were playing fee for games every week across the world. Madden NFL Mobile
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Q3 was an outstanding quarter for Electronic Arts. Dragon Age: Inquisition was named to more than 200 game of the year globally. More than 6 million people on average were playing fee for games every week across the world. Madden NFL Mobile has its biggest game in franchise history on Christmas Day reaching #4 on the top grossing chart in the U.S. Apple App Store, and we finished the calendar year as the world's leading console games publisher, a testament to the strength and breadth of EA's IP. Our excellent financial results reflect the strong player engagement and critical success of our titles. 
Revenue and earnings for Q3 were beyond our guidance, and we delivered another quarter of strong cash flow. At the core, we continue to focus on putting players first. As we listen, learn and deliver for our communities with games and services that they love to pay, we are experiencing new milestones and engagement. On console and PC platforms above, more than 3.1 billion hours were spent playing EA games in Q3. Dragon Age: Inquisition captivated fans and critics worldwide as it launched in November and it quickly became the most successful launch in BioWare history. More than 113 million hours have already been spent exploring the depth and detail of the single-payer experience in Dragon Age: Inquisition, and more players are joining each day. Named Game of the Year by 32 media outlets around the world, including IGN, Gaming Format and the Associated Press, Dragon Age: Inquisition is a true masterpiece from a team of BioWare and again, that is sure to be played for a long time to come. 
FIFA 15 and Madden NFL 15 also continued to deliver for fans in our third quarter. FIFA 15 was the #1 title in Europe and a top 10 title in the U.S. in 2014 with engagement growing in Q3. There were nearly 50% more users logging in each week as compared to Q3 last year. Meanwhile, Madden NFL 15 was the #2 best-selling title in North America for 2014 across of the whole genres and gameplay hours were up 30% year-on-year in Q3. 
In our Ultimate Team services, engagement is deeper than ever. The total number of players entering Ultimate Team across FIFA 15, Madden NFL 15 and NHL 15 has increased nearly 45% year-over-year. Our Maxis GPO delivered 3 major game updates to The Sims -- in Q3, providing some new content and adding some of the most wanted community features. Each update is driven more players to engage with The Sims 4, and we are planting to continue delivering first content and gameplay to the vibrant community. EA Mobile had double breakout performance over the holiday period. Our EA SPORTS title are enjoying more sports fans in the mobile games averaging more than 45 million monthly active users during the quarter. Madden NFL Mobile and FIFA 15 Ultimate Team of -- away averaging 45% monthly players are through Q3 compared to our previous iterations in the same period last year. The newly launched the SimCity BuildIt was downloaded more than 22 million time in the first month, reached the top 5 iOS game downloads in more than 100 countries and the date plays have already logged more than 1.2 billion gameplay sessions. New games like Madden NFL Mobile, FIFA 15 Ultimate Team and SimCity BuildIt as well as fans favorites like Real Racing 3, The Sims FreePlay and The Simpsons: Tapped Out, demonstrate one of our key opportunities in mobile. Leveraging our IP and specifically designing experiences from the ground up for players and mobile devices. We are listening and learning from the feedback in our mobile community, the experience is based on testing and soft launch the periods that keeping players entertained with new content and challenges. Overall the momentum that we are seeing across different platforms today gives us good reason to be cited for the future. 
On consoles, the installed base on Xbox wanted PlayStation 4 continues to show strong growth. While new playing joining on previous generation consoles are also tapping into our amazing IP catalogue. 
On mobile, innovative games are opening up new growth genres like sports, with highly engaged players. On PC, our Origin service continues to grow fiscal year-to-date and offer exciting new ways to play. Across all of these platforms, live services are extending the experience and bringing players deeper into the game they love. With the dynamite nature of this industry, platform preferences, play your interest, play patents and game experiences were constantly evolved. We are confident that through our efforts to put players first, to continue to digitally transform our business and to operate faster and more focused theme we will be in a position of strength of the make industry changes our greatest opportunity. I'll now hand the call over to Blake for a deeper look at Q3 financial performance, then I'll return with a few final thoughts.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.43 billion, which was $153 million or 12% above guidance. The quarter's revenue was only 9% lower than the prior years, which included the launch of a Battlefield 4. However, our focus on live services, str
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.43 billion, which was $153 million or 12% above guidance. The quarter's revenue was only 9% lower than the prior years, which included the launch of a Battlefield 4. However, our focus on live services, strong title performance and expense control drove operating margins up significantly this quarter with 36.3% from 33.8% last year. And this resulted in an excellent cash generation and earnings. This extraordinary performance was led by FIFA 15, Madden NFL 15 and Dragon Age: Inquisition. In particular, Dragon Age: Inquisition have, by far, the most successful launch in BioWare's history, exceeding our expectations. In addition, game sales for less generation consoles were also much stronger when we anticipated. FX make a few revenue by about $20 million this quarter, but our program offset about half of this and combined with a natural hedging from our international operations, largely neutralized this impact on earnings. 
Our non-GAAP digital net revenue for the quarter increased 34.4% year-over-year to $693 million, 49% of this quarter's revenue and a new high. The trailing 12-month the digital net revenue was also a record, up 17% to $2.18 billion. This is the first-time digital sales have generated more than half our revenue in a 12-month period. 
Breaking down our digital revenue into its key components highlights the performance of each of these businesses this quarter. Extra content and a premium contributed $314 million, up of 47% over the prior year, with Ultimate Team continuing its strong performance across our FIFA, Madden NFL and NHL franchises, up 82% year-over-year in total. FIFA Online 3 in Korea continues to grow year-over-year, and the early litigations from our partner in China, Tencent, are that it is already a forming it's terribly well. Star Wars of The Old Republic also contracted to the segment with the expansion the Shadows of Raven, attracting many more people into the game with its epic storyline. Star Wars remains deeply engage in The Old Republic universe and we're more excited to see how that will build as we get closer to the launch of the Star Wars movie this December. 
Mobile generated a record $139 million in the quarter, up 13% over the prior period. $125 million or 90% of this was from digital extra content and advertising. This was up 28% versus the prior year and continues to more than offset the decline in the freemium business. Premium full game download revenue was just $14 million down the 44% compared to the prior year. Mobile had a strong December in particular, driven by the success of SimCity BuildIt, Madden NFL Mobile and FIFA 15 Ultimate Team mobile as well as the continued strength of the rest of our mobile portfolio. Leveraging proven IP like this reduces of the cost of player acquisition and drive of the long-term profitability of our mobile business. SimCity BuildIt has proven to be a highly engaging title that has been a top 10 grossing 1 on iPhone in 85 countries and on iPad in more than 100. Full game PC and console downloads and generated $140 million in revenue, up 22% over the prior year, driven by growth in the installed base PS4 and Xbox One consoles. Although the percentage vary considerably by title, platform and geography, the trend towards full game downloads continues. Subscriptions, advertising and other digital revenue contributed $100 million, up 52% over the same period last year. The primary growth driver was Battlefield 4 Premium revenues, EA Access, our subscription for Xbox 1 continues to grow and we're seeing subscribers play more games, engage more broadly with the EA's offerings. 
Moving onto gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 72.8%, an increase from last year's 68.1% and better than our guidance of 70.5%. The increase over the prior year was primarily due to the growth in our digital business, strength encourage generation consoles and a onetime benefit from an -- revenue deferred to the second quarter. This was partially offset by the higher proportion of sales from a royalty-bearing titles in the quarter compared to last year's Q3. Outperformance versus our outlook was driven by the record-breaking Dragon Age: Inquisition performance. In addition, sell-through was extremely healthy across the market, enabling us to maintain margin above our expectations while keeping channel inventory clean. 
Our non-GAAP operating expense in the quarter were $521 million, down 4% year-on-year. $19 million below prior year, but $6 million above our guidance. Compared to last year, we were able to continue to reduce advertising spend by focusing on a few were frontline titles and increasing the efficiency of the way we advertise. This was partially offset by an increase in the accruals we made from a variable compensation and legal expenses, which were not in our guidance. The resulting non-GAAP diluted EPS was $1.22 per share, $0.32 better than guidance due to strong revenue, higher gross margin and continued cost control. Our cash and short-term investments at the end of the quarter were 2.94 billion -- or approximately $9.48 per share. 56 of this cash is short-term investment balance, which help on sure. Net cash provided by operating activities for the quarter were $682 million. On a trailing 12-month basis, operating cash flow was $1.15 billion, a record for this period. 
During Q3, we repurchased 2.5 million shares at a cost of $97 million. As a reminder, our $750 million buyback was initiated in May 2014 and has a 2-year time frame. The current rate of purchase keeps us on track to complete the full $750 million in that time. 
Turning to guidance. We're increasing our full year guidance. For fiscal year 2015, our non-GAAP guidance for revenue will increase by $78 million to $4.253 billion and our non-GAAP EPS will be increased by $0.30 to $2.35 per share. This resulted in expected operating margin of nearly 24%. Although this guidance passed through essentially all the Q3 earnings outperformance for the full year, it does not pass through all the revenue. The reduction in our Q4 revenue expectation is based on uncertainty around future currency movements and the decision to move EA SPORTS, PGA TOUR and the first Sims 4 expansion pack into fiscal '16. In addition, there is uncertainty as to when we will start to recognize revenue from a FIFA Online 3 in China. However, gross margin improvement and continued expense control offset this conservatism in revenue, allowing us to substantially reaffirm our Q4 earnings expectation. The GAAP guidance becomes $4.485 billion in revenue and $2.57 in fully diluted EPS. 
Regarding cash flow for the full fiscal year, we are increasing our operating cash flow guidance to approximately $1.05 billion, which will be the largest fiscal year cash flow in the company's history. Our capital expend forecast remains approximately $100 million, resulting in a new free cash flow forecast of approximately $950 million. Guidance for our fourth quarter is now non-GAAP net revenue to be $830 million, a 9% decrease compared to last year's $914 million. Year-on-year difference is largely driven by Battlefield 4 catalogue sales, which were very strong in Q4 fiscal '14. The quarter, we immediately after we ship to Battlefield. 
Our next major launch title, Battlefield Hardline, we'll start to ship the 3rd-week of March, so it's impact on the quarter will be limited, even though we expected this to build into a significant title through the next fiscal year. Non-GAAP gross margin is forecasted to be 74%. We expect our Q4 operating expenses to be $515 million on a non-GAAP basis. This resulted in a non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.22 per share as compared to $0.48 last year. Our Q4 guidance for GAAP net revenue is expected to be $1.16 billion as compared to $1.12 billion in the prior year. GAAP earnings per share is expected to be $1.07 as compared to $1.15 per share in the prior year. We're pleased with our third quarter results and, most importantly, with the consistent growth of cash flow and earnings. We're well ahead of where we expect to be at this stage of the transformation, largely as a result of the strength of our digital lives of is a strategy, our ability to control costs and the continued great commitment of our employees to drive performance. But there's plenty more of opportunities ahead of us. We expect these factors will continue to drive growth and cash flow earnings and to be augmented by a growing mobile business as we continue to apply our core IP at this platform. Now I'll turn the call back to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: Thanks, Blake. It was a great Q3 and is more to excited about as he we look to Q4 and beyond. The launch of Battlefield Hardline will be. The culmination of efforts by the team -- and across EA to engage our players and deliver of reach and innovative new experience. Battlefield Hardline and the first combination of speed, story and strategy, a mix of engaging single player campaign in inspired by you multiply our experiences and classic Battlefield multiplayer modes. We're getting great response to the game in recent playtest and we look forward to opening up into the community with the upcoming multiplayer Beta. This is a fast, fun and intense new experience and we thank players are going to love it. We look forward to Battlefield the beginning on March 17. Our fight for the coming year demonstrates EA's commitment to through brand new experiences as well as our lot services. Players in our current experiences including Dragon Age acquisition, The Sims 4, the EA SPORTS portfolio and Battlefield 4, will continue to see update and new content in the future. We will now launch PGA TOUR in Q1 FY '16 in line with the some of the golf's biggest tournaments and will be joined by a lineup of annual EA SPORTS title next year. A Need for Speed franchise will return in FY '16 when I get that is already looking spectacular. And of course, the new blockbuster Star Wars Battlefront is set to release in the holiday quarter this year. We share our full FY '16 calendar, including a slide of new mobile games it during our next quarterly call. As its earlier in the call, that the very nature of the games industry is a dynamic and constantly evolving. This place to the strength of all Electronic Arts. Change is one of the constants in history of this company, and we continue to change ourselves to listen, learn and lead an exciting new future for gaming and for our players. You'll see us focus on our play relationships to engage and understand what inspires each gamers they play. You see us in vetting and in new IP and innovation from ground up new experiences to cutting edge digital services. And you will see us focus on quality at every turn. The ability and our services and delivery of a long-lasting fund with games that are played a 4 months and years, not just days or weeks. Throughout FY '13, EA has focused on supporting our players a first and strengthening the foundation of our business. We know look forward to a strong finish in Q4 and carrying momentum from FY '13 into FY '16. Now, Blake, Peter, Frank and I are now here for your questions.

componenttext: I guess, first off, following on the commentary regarding the full game downloads, console games. I wonder if you can quantify the mix of digital versus physical? And then how much of the downloads are driven by promotions and bundles? And then secondly, regarding the market for last gen games. You mentioned and these segment exceeded your expectations. I'm wondering if you can now say that the portion of that market has stabilized? Or is that specific to where you are going over the holiday period?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Colin, it's Peter. so 100% of full game of download digital from a mix perspective. As I said on previous calls, we're seeing about 15% of our sales come from full-game downloads by primarily the Sony and Microsoft platforms across as well as our Origin p
componenttext: Colin, it's Peter. so 100% of full game of download digital from a mix perspective. As I said on previous calls, we're seeing about 15% of our sales come from full-game downloads by primarily the Sony and Microsoft platforms across as well as our Origin platform. I will say in the last couple of weeks to your question, that we've seen an interesting and encouraging pickup in our sports titles in particular where we're seeing a significant increase above that number for full game downloads on the console and PC platforms. As regards current gen or Xbox 360 PS3 platforms, we saw about $100 million in incremental revenue in Q3 on those platforms, I think driven by number of factors. I think it's being great value for consumers to pick those consuls up at this page in their life cycle. I think Sony and Microsoft continue to support them well. There's a great portfolio of titles. And in particular, what Electronic Arts brings is blockbuster IP that gamers are very familiar with and there are relatively easy purchases. We're also seeing strong digital pick up on those platforms as well.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Colin, it's Blake. just to follow up on Peter's comment on the full game downloads. I think you asked trying to get a sense of how much of that was coming from bundling. We did have some bundles in the quarter but not substantially more than what we would
componenttext: Colin, it's Blake. just to follow up on Peter's comment on the full game downloads. I think you asked trying to get a sense of how much of that was coming from bundling. We did have some bundles in the quarter but not substantially more than what we would normally have. So the real full game download trend is being driven primarily by full game downloads on the new generation consoles. One phenomenon that we do see in the Christmas holiday, that people like to give a physical gift that it's been in the tree -- whatever you do you're giftgiving. And so often times, we don't see the pickup in full game downloads until after people have played their first round of games they've gotten for Christmas presents. And Peter's point while we've seen just most recent pickup in the last couple of weeks of full game downloads, which were tied back to the notion that people are now starting to really understand the power if there any consuls and starting to pick up that.

I think we're optimistic that, that will continue to grow as we go into FY '16 particular. But a great start towards the EA Access.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So now for efforts. We have hedging program in place where the objective is to reduce the impact of currency moves on operating income and cash flow. And in addition to actually get a natural hedge based on the fact that we have a substantial number of em
componenttext: So now for efforts. We have hedging program in place where the objective is to reduce the impact of currency moves on operating income and cash flow. And in addition to actually get a natural hedge based on the fact that we have a substantial number of employees and offices in Europe as well as in Canada. And we tend to focus on 4 core courses, the euro, the British pound, the Canadian dollar and the Swedish kroner, which are really go for core centers of where we have employees as well as where our core revenue exist. We are exposed to other currencies beyond that because they're not as large in the overall mix. The reality is that we're able to hedge our revenue but rarely can we hedge 100% of that. We're able to hedge partially because of actual hedges and partially because of natural hedges more of our operating income swing to see a larger swing on the top line and we do in the bottom line. This quarter, we saw virtually no impact on the bottom line and as I said about a $20 million impact on the top line. The real unknown for us going forward is exactly what we think operating or the euro is going to look like 6 to 9 months after where our hedges are less impactful going forward. We'll know more when we give guidance in May for the full year. We see a little risk in the fourth quarter if you see continued decline in euro. But I think the bigger unknown for us is what does the euro look like all through our next fiscal year and that present we'll give you an update and we're doing our best to try to hedge out to try to possible.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Arvind. Great question. As we look at the year ahead, we are very confident, we're seeing continued uptake of PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. The new boost that we have through with this quarter on what with Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 is also very goo
componenttext: Thanks, Arvind. Great question. As we look at the year ahead, we are very confident, we're seeing continued uptake of PlayStation 4 and Xbox One. The new boost that we have through with this quarter on what with Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 is also very good for us. Again, we have a very, very strong portfolio of titles. And we would expect that we will continue to benefit as a both generations of consoles continue to show strength and growth, albeit for different markets, given the breath and the strength of our portfolio. In addition to that, we're seeing continued engagement with our live services and players playing longer and engaging deeper with those live services across a both generations of console. And as we've talked about, we have very strong quarter with respect to mobile, and we're starting to see the value of our IP combined with the learning experiences that we've had over the past couple of years with respect to mobile. So all in all, when we think about 2 console generations of strength, we think about ongoing engagement with our live services and we start to see there's -- the benefit of the learning and the strength of our portfolio of mobile. We feel very good about the year ahead.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: When it comes operating margin, we're not yet ready to get that sort of next year's guidance or even long-term guidance on operating model, but we woke, in May, talk a little bit about multiple year potential here. I do -- I'll use the time to remind peop
componenttext: When it comes operating margin, we're not yet ready to get that sort of next year's guidance or even long-term guidance on operating model, but we woke, in May, talk a little bit about multiple year potential here. I do -- I'll use the time to remind people that we -- about 2.5 years ago, we were in the single-digit area. And through focus of the entire organization and the former management team, we are really pushed the change on how we operate, both from a consumer perspective, very focused on the gamer-first mentality and second, on a financial perspective. And that's allowed us to move into what looks like now, roughly 24% operating margin for the year with obviously this quarter showing operating margins well into the mid-30s. We do believe that we've got potential continued upside on the gross margin side of the business as we finish our digital business. And as we add more and more revenue via either digital live services or mobile, we think that will continue to benefit through some operating leverage and give us more operating upside. We kind of view the first stage of this change as the turnaround. We feel that that's been down and really talk to focus on the transition and transformation that we believe has the potential here, driving much harder operating margins of cash flows over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

How does that compared to the launch in Korea just in terms of user growth and modernization?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll start with a cash flow and then Andrew or Peter can weigh in on FIFA in China. Cash flow was a couple of benefit. One is just obviously, the strength of the business across the board and the strength and our physical retail partners,  I think, hel
componenttext: So I'll start with a cash flow and then Andrew or Peter can weigh in on FIFA in China. Cash flow was a couple of benefit. One is just obviously, the strength of the business across the board and the strength and our physical retail partners,  I think, helps. People think faster when they are in a stronger position. And then, second, our digital business, obviously, view was a much faster cash and action cycle. There's a relatively little inventory in the channel. That's a very good positive for us and all of that comes together to try to drive significantly upside on our cash flow. We've been continuing to manage our CapEx aggressively. And that's helping the free cash flow side of the business. But I'd say the bulk of it is really just a flow through from real strength and the operating earnings that are coming out of the business as we're really hitting on all cylinders.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And, Chris, this is Pete. Our FIFA Online 3 in China, as you know, being published by -- Tencent there. We still get to get to the official launch, but we're in a very strong soft launch period right now. Tencent themselves announced in December that they
componenttext: And, Chris, this is Pete. Our FIFA Online 3 in China, as you know, being published by -- Tencent there. We still get to get to the official launch, but we're in a very strong soft launch period right now. Tencent themselves announced in December that they have reached 500,000 peak concurrent users, which are in a new record for sports title in that marketplace. So all of the key indicators are very, very positive. When expect at some point in this quarter to go fully live and then as we mentioned in our prepared remarks, we're yet to determine when to recognize revenue against this title. But all key indications are that this is a record-breaking start. We're very optimistic. But more primarily an impact on FY '16 at this point.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Olson from Piper Jaffrey.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're talking about high engagement in live services and moving from a transition phase to kind of a transformation phase. Can you give us a sense of how you envision EA's business model will evolve maybe over the next 3 to 5 years. I realized light year
componenttext: You're talking about high engagement in live services and moving from a transition phase to kind of a transformation phase. Can you give us a sense of how you envision EA's business model will evolve maybe over the next 3 to 5 years. I realized light years away from now, but how should we think about EA's mix of revenue from newer business models like subscription or free-to-play or other digital models and maybe kind of compare it to traditional retail physical disc sales, et cetera?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew. As Blake has talked about, as Peter has talked about, we're definitely seeing a greater trend towards digital revenue. And over this quarter, certainly, that trend continued. As we look to the future and we think about the various opportun
componenttext: This is Andrew. As Blake has talked about, as Peter has talked about, we're definitely seeing a greater trend towards digital revenue. And over this quarter, certainly, that trend continued. As we look to the future and we think about the various opportunities inside of digital revenue, we look a lot at our adjacent media companies that provide music and television and movies and recognize it an opportunity for us is to capture the greatest possible share through the offering of multiple consumption models models. So as we've talked about on the call to the past, we've been investing for some years now in the digital platform that will facilitate trends actions in any number of ways, either through a free-to-play market or transaction driven model, a premium download model or subscription model or some combination of those things. So as we think about our digital future, we are really looking at various platforms, various markets and various business models in that and looking to offer that in a way that any particular player might want to consume the great games that we make.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: The next question comes from Justin Post of Bank of America.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Gee calling in for Justin Post. Two quick questions on the digital business. First,, it's encouraging to see the growth of Ultimate Team, both players and sales. I was wondering if you could talk some of the drivers last quarter? Was there an
componenttext: This is Ryan Gee calling in for Justin Post. Two quick questions on the digital business. First,, it's encouraging to see the growth of Ultimate Team, both players and sales. I was wondering if you could talk some of the drivers last quarter? Was there any in particular about this year, last year we need to keep in mind and whether this growth trend that you're seeing there is sustainable? And then second, the growth in Ultimate Team compares to the mobile business, which around 13% is tracking below the digital average. Can you talk about your plan to either reaccelerate that business or it's feature phone? Or there's still a headwind that we should be looking at going forward?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. When we started I can talk to Frank. No one reminder that go for -- underlying growth in mobile is really 28% if you pull that business out, which legacy for us is down to about $14 million a year and declining year-over-year. We can't force
componenttext: This is Greg. When we started I can talk to Frank. No one reminder that go for -- underlying growth in mobile is really 28% if you pull that business out, which legacy for us is down to about $14 million a year and declining year-over-year. We can't force it out any faster than what we're already doing because it's embedded in the lot of where people play games in there. But Frank can talk about exciting growth idea as well as growth that greasing in the mobile business. First, just on the Ultimate Team side of the equation, the key for us for the Ultimate Team right now has been discovery, making sure people understand what it is and how exciting and fun it is. So smaller portion of people to buy the game less than half of people actually entering to Ultimate Team and a small fraction of those people actually get heavily involved in Ultimate Team and ultimately monetize. And so part of our goal is increasing visibility of Ultimate Team and making sure that people understand how to play it and how fun it is. So you see when you load up the for the first time, you see Ultimate Team, pointer screen. We're try to make sure people understand, get into the fun essentially and understand how passionate and powerful it is you start to play it. And we're trying to encourage people to play with Air France and so you'll see more of that to the Ultimate Team. Clearly, as the scales today, your question, how much larger connected, but were surprised every quarter about continued growth and we do know particularly how much people love and particularly how much opportunity there could still be going forward. So exciting times ahead and we're looking at ways that we can leverage Ultimate Team mechanic and more games than in the nonsports style game.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Frank. The question on mobile, really, what I draw your attention to is the new release that we put out with Madden, FIFA and since SimCity BuildIt, which will as premium services. We spent the first part of this year, taking the best and brightes
componenttext: This is Frank. The question on mobile, really, what I draw your attention to is the new release that we put out with Madden, FIFA and since SimCity BuildIt, which will as premium services. We spent the first part of this year, taking the best and brightest from inside Electronic Arts as well as from outside, bringing in the industry to build a world-class mobile team. And those 3 products really represent what we believe the future potential of big brands with natural, organic acquisitions advantages couple coupled with great quality, great technology and a focus on engagement in life services it represents. So in the quarter, if you strip away the headwind from the premium download business, we are growing around the 28%, but that growth actually accelerated as we step into December and we picked up share there with the releases of SimCity BuildIt. At we look into '16 and beyond, our next product is Need for Speed builder, another huge brand that will do very well. We will build it from the grand up, premium service live. We really bullish on how does that going forward and really drive that growth rate that's currently the high 20s to something that we're pretty proud of.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. One follow-up quick question, if I may. We saw in the NPD, the retail did in December that there were some weakness in the average selling prices, particularly on the new GEN consoles. Is that something that you guys have seen in early Januar
componenttext: Okay, great. One follow-up quick question, if I may. We saw in the NPD, the retail did in December that there were some weakness in the average selling prices, particularly on the new GEN consoles. Is that something that you guys have seen in early January continue? And is that something we should be concerned about it maybe in '15, just faster price-cutting by retailers?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't believe so. I think, Ryan, what you were saying is maybe some short-term promotional as retailers particularly here in North America, were trying to get market share over the holiday period. I think we understand I haven't seen that my team in
componenttext: No, I don't believe so. I think, Ryan, what you were saying is maybe some short-term promotional as retailers particularly here in North America, were trying to get market share over the holiday period. I think we understand I haven't seen that my team in the field hasn't seen it. I think what you saw was a short-term debt.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And you guys have heard me say this before, but I'll say again but you have to be really careful using NPD data becoming less and less valuable but more and more of the business is going digital. And there's obviously, not a digital comparison to it, but
componenttext: And you guys have heard me say this before, but I'll say again but you have to be really careful using NPD data becoming less and less valuable but more and more of the business is going digital. And there's obviously, not a digital comparison to it, but both in volume and in, it pricing can be sometimes very a fairly large distraction and when you add it, then there's no international piece to it. There really understood the strength of our business and I think as you can see in the quarter.

componenttext: Next question comes from Drew Crum with Stifel.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you can comment further around Battlefield Hardline. I think you suggested that, that would not be material for fiscal fourth quarter numbers. Is that from a revenue perspective? Or is that the profit as well? And should we expect most of it t
componenttext: I wonder if you can comment further around Battlefield Hardline. I think you suggested that, that would not be material for fiscal fourth quarter numbers. Is that from a revenue perspective? Or is that the profit as well? And should we expect most of it to ship on the first quarter fiscal '16? And then on gross margin, I have 2 questions. Can you pull out the NHL benefit you saw in the quarter? And then, Blake, just kind of thinking longer term, your gross margin guidance for fiscal '15 is now about 70% but digital is a little more than 50% of total non-GAAP revenue. Any thoughts on longer-term gross margin upside for the business?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Drew. Don't take my comments on Hardline to be in any way negative. It was simply to say that we don't ship it until the 3rd week of March. And so it's primarily a sell in only and we'll see a very large impact as we roll into next year with
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Drew. Don't take my comments on Hardline to be in any way negative. It was simply to say that we don't ship it until the 3rd week of March. And so it's primarily a sell in only and we'll see a very large impact as we roll into next year with that title. As an example, right now, the levels of people playing Battlefield 4, some of the highest we've seen in the last year. And so people play and buy Battlefield products for a long time into the future. And so we think the selling will be very strong for Hardline. It would be very important for the quarter, but I think it's a very strong indicator going forward.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to add to Blake's comments there. It's a great window for us and our retailers around the world see this late March window. To Blake's point, not hugely material for the quarter because it will be what we call an initial purchase quantity or one
componenttext: Yes, just to add to Blake's comments there. It's a great window for us and our retailers around the world see this late March window. To Blake's point, not hugely material for the quarter because it will be what we call an initial purchase quantity or one day load in and then a little bit of replenishment, huge opportunity, I think, for FY '16. But retailers and like GameStop here in North America in particular, we see the same this is a go big title, I'm really getting behind it. And we see the same across the rest of the world. I think it's a huge opportunity for us to be able to establish a new option to the franchise that is Battlefield. As I said, it's a one-shot on the quarter, but FY '16 looks very strong and we would look at our forecast for this title.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as Andrew mentioned, the speed and the excitement of the game exceeds almost anything we've done in the Battlefield franchise. And I think that kind of really gets people by surprise. And you're going to see a lot of people -- the momentum is going t
componenttext: Yes, as Andrew mentioned, the speed and the excitement of the game exceeds almost anything we've done in the Battlefield franchise. And I think that kind of really gets people by surprise. And you're going to see a lot of people -- the momentum is going to build on it as more and more people start to play at and what their friends to be able to comment and play it. The things you're able to do with vehicles, with weapons in the urban centers of this, just almost unbelievable. And you'll start to see more and more screens and more and more live game over the few weeks as we start to crank the marketing activities and, obviously, the beta that Andrew mentioned. So more to come there, it's pretty exciting now. On the gross margin side, NHL was under $50 million in terms of revenues that was deferred into the quarter. And so that really probably took gross margins up by about 1 point relative to the overall -- over delivery of gross margin. And so it obviously, helped us that's why we wanted to call it out. We did that because we have more to deliver on NHL than we did during the quarter and that's why we differed some of the NHL revenue. I think longer term, gross margin, more to come when we give guidance next year, but we do believe that we could operate in 30 -- or excuse me, 72% to 74% gross margin longer term. This year, we're in the 70% to 71% and in a couple of quarters, that will be higher than that. But we do believe there's potentially, as we continue to ship that digital business and a lot of services, what moving forward. So more to come on that.

componenttext: Yes. So first on the title. You should assume all the first titles obviously, will be on their regular rotation. I would assume that we're going to continue to try to double down as we mentioned on Ultimate Team and try to expand that business. We have Need for Speed back in the rotation next year, which is the positive as Frank mentioned there's an Need for Speed coming on mobile, but also we're going to have another a couple of unannounced their exotic mobile titles as well in the quarter during the year. And then, last but far from least, we got the Battlefront Star Wars title coming in before Christmas next year aligned with the Star Wars movie roll out. We're extremely excited about that and we think there's huge potential for that title. More to come in the next couple of months on that as more about the movie comes out as well as a more about our titles, out. But you should consider that is a very large activity for us next year, and a very large focus. We thought about Battlefield in the past.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your thoughts on headcount, Blake?
componenttext: And your thoughts on headcount, Blake?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: On headcount, I think our focus is margin and cost discipline will not stop. We're very focused on that. Were focused on what that means for headcount around the world as well as marketing spend around the world and that's going to -- that focus is going
componenttext: On headcount, I think our focus is margin and cost discipline will not stop. We're very focused on that. Were focused on what that means for headcount around the world as well as marketing spend around the world and that's going to -- that focus is going to stay. So you should see a dramatic change in the headcount, probably think about it roughly as -- And really, our challenge is how do we offset some of the natural increases in compensation cost during the year and we've got everybody to drive efficiency it through their business to try to offset some of that. We're remaking some of the headcount that we're moving towards live services. That means more customer service, more live service management. And that will have to be offset by reductions in other places where we can balance that headcount. So we can mix the headcount amongst what people do in their day job.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the last question for me is just curious how you think about the free-to-play becoming more viable business model for consoles via the medium-term particularly for the sort of multiplayer only experience that's starting to take -- starting to pop up a
componenttext: And the last question for me is just curious how you think about the free-to-play becoming more viable business model for consoles via the medium-term particularly for the sort of multiplayer only experience that's starting to take -- starting to pop up a little bit more than prior cycle?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Andrew. On free-to-play with consoles, with think about this much as we think about the free-to-play overall. And there's a couple of different factors to this. The first is as we look into the future, we believe a very big part of our player b
componenttext: So this is Andrew. On free-to-play with consoles, with think about this much as we think about the free-to-play overall. And there's a couple of different factors to this. The first is as we look into the future, we believe a very big part of our player base with experienced of free-to-start experience. When you look at film, television, music, books, very often there's a very free tryout notion that actually on board new players, new listeners, new readers or new viewers into a service. And we're actively looking at how we could offer that title of experience our players, console and across other platforms. From there, it really comes down to do they make their next up in terms of a premium download, a micro- transaction into free-to-play tough environment? Or a broader relationship through of subscription. And our expectation is that we will be offering all 3 of those options to players, both on consoles and across other platforms.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Sean McGowan from pleegam.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-up questions from earlier one. Blake, on the hedging, I just want to be clear, are you actively engaging and trying to hedge more than just the transaction that you have? And extend that into translation?
componenttext: A couple of follow-up questions from earlier one. Blake, on the hedging, I just want to be clear, are you actively engaging and trying to hedge more than just the transaction that you have? And extend that into translation?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have both balance sheet, cash flow as well as earnings, and we're hedging essentially their core currency that where we operate around the world. So think about it as effectively trying to minimize the swings in exchange rate. The impact of the
componenttext: Yes. So we have both balance sheet, cash flow as well as earnings, and we're hedging essentially their core currency that where we operate around the world. So think about it as effectively trying to minimize the swings in exchange rate. The impact of the swings in exchange rates on our P&L, on our balance sheet. We don't try to play bets, to try to make money on hedges. We simply are trying to offset swings that could occur. So ideally for us, it would be for constantly neutral, any currency moves. Obviously, that's hard to do and it gets expensive. And so when you see rapid changes in FX like we've seen in the last 6 weeks, it's harder to be able to protect against that over a long-term period of time. It just gets very expensive to do. So we are constantly -- what we have rolling hedges rolling over time to smooth our hedging and we try to make sure that we're protecting both revenue line, but most importantly, the cash flow in the earnings line.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is it safe to say that the driving assumption as you enter in those hedge transactions is that the current rate persists? Or you're making some bet about the direction?
componenttext: So is it safe to say that the driving assumption as you enter in those hedge transactions is that the current rate persists? Or you're making some bet about the direction?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll make some bet about the direction, but we're not try to make bit about the direction of make money, per se, to simply protect it where our cash flows are coming from.
componenttext: We'll make some bet about the direction, but we're not try to make bit about the direction of make money, per se, to simply protect it where our cash flows are coming from.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I'm not sure we should take the next question because it with refers back to the stability that were now seeing in the old general previous generation sales. We see zigging and zagging in recent quarters about that. So if the stability is
componenttext: That's helpful. I'm not sure we should take the next question because it with refers back to the stability that were now seeing in the old general previous generation sales. We see zigging and zagging in recent quarters about that. So if the stability is more a function of your expectations, given better round? Or is there really a change in the marketplace going on?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think Sean this is Peter. I don't think there's a change. We're entering the 9th-year of the cycle here. So we're -- I think we're seeing the strong tail. I think both Sony and Microsoft are there providing support behind the air current GEN betwe
componenttext: I don't think Sean this is Peter. I don't think there's a change. We're entering the 9th-year of the cycle here. So we're -- I think we're seeing the strong tail. I think both Sony and Microsoft are there providing support behind the air current GEN between both Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3. It's having that side of the business as you well remember it's a strong opportunity for both of these to continue to leverage the power that very large installed base. There's a good portfolio of title, the trenches back 9 years. The hardware is great value for money for consumers that haven't jumped in yet for a console hardware. We were concerned with we call probably 2 or 3 quarters ago that all of the action was in Xbox once NPS force. But I think what happened is that that consumers moved on the display and to consumers looking to get involved in games. Great deals for retailers around the world in Q3 and the holiday period. And our job of these to be able to take full advantage of that, and nobody in the industry has more recognizable blockbusters DNA Electronic Arts. And I think it's as simple as that. Our teams are well-positioned with the content, with our retail partners as well as full game downloads of those titles. And this is where great brands, great IP shines. With consumers looking for recognized content. So I think you can characterize it as a stable situation. I think as we look at our FY '16 numbers, we expect that to continue and to take full advantage of it.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: There were -- during the year, there were roughly 3 million all generation consoles sold here in the U.S. And a half of that came in the last 2 months of the year. So obviously, Christmas discounting, probably drove a lot of that sales. And if your biking
componenttext: There were -- during the year, there were roughly 3 million all generation consoles sold here in the U.S. And a half of that came in the last 2 months of the year. So obviously, Christmas discounting, probably drove a lot of that sales. And if your biking a console for the first time, as Peter said, there's a high probability that they're going to go back seat for a matted or Need for Speed or one of the titles, Battlefield titles, the people really know a great titles to play.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim O'Shea from Jefferies.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Another quarter on balance sheet. You guys ended the calendar year with over $2.9 billion in cash and equivalents. And buy my math, I think that's around for about $2.1 billion last year. Just given the elevated levels that I thought I'd maybe pension wit
componenttext: Another quarter on balance sheet. You guys ended the calendar year with over $2.9 billion in cash and equivalents. And buy my math, I think that's around for about $2.1 billion last year. Just given the elevated levels that I thought I'd maybe pension with respect to things how much cash you need on the balance sheet, about share repurchases and maybe even know when this 0.75% convertible notes that are due 2016. Just wondering if you're thinking as involved as the balance continue to rise. And then I have a quick follow-up.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So clearly, we have flexibility that we get more and more cash on the balance sheet. We're very focused on making sure that, that cash go back to shareholders in a most efficient way. We do, as we think about cash needs obviously, we need think gener
componenttext: Yes. So clearly, we have flexibility that we get more and more cash on the balance sheet. We're very focused on making sure that, that cash go back to shareholders in a most efficient way. We do, as we think about cash needs obviously, we need think general operating needs and we are always waiting on notion that now 60% of that cash is sitting on shore, but that's a benefit from the repatriation that we did 1.5 years ago or 1 year ago. There's a natural cash build that occurs internationally and so that will start to deplete over time and we'll go back to probably a greater cash balance internationally and domestically. Also, waiting on our thinking as the current converts due you in August next year, August calendar year '15 -- '16, excuse me. And we're thinking through ways, in which we either can refinance those or pay those off. But the clearly ways on how much cash we hold that needs to the -- And last not the least, we're fairly committed to continue to buyback stock. We are on track, be able to complete 750 million to your buyback and as we generate more cash, we'll consider greater buybacks over time. It's not obligated. I think we just need to have a simple model, which is a guy we get back to shareholders.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just looking at guidance. It doesn't -- through a portion of the just full year. Just sharing if there's anything out there in the March quarter that made your -- a bit more cautious, perhaps a running faster or maybe this looks like some general
componenttext: And then just looking at guidance. It doesn't -- through a portion of the just full year. Just sharing if there's anything out there in the March quarter that made your -- a bit more cautious, perhaps a running faster or maybe this looks like some general conservatism on your behalf.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, unfortunately, I guess, we're starting to think we're conservative over time. I guess, we are, which is a good thing. I do remind people, we started the year with guidance of $4.1 billion and $1.85 in EPS. And some of the original conversations
componenttext: Yes, well, unfortunately, I guess, we're starting to think we're conservative over time. I guess, we are, which is a good thing. I do remind people, we started the year with guidance of $4.1 billion and $1.85 in EPS. And some of the original conversations I had with people thought we were crazy to guide that high. And obviously, now we're $4.253 billion and $2.35. As I've said on the call, maybe neighbor major drivers now flowing through all $150 million of the revenue was, first, we decided to move titles out of the quarter, small titles, but titles nonetheless. PGA gold and the first Sims expansion pack will both fall in the Q1 no. Those are originally in our thinking for Q4. To that end, we don't know where the efforts is going to go. I don't think it's going to carry a lot more bit but when the euro was $1.30. So there is some uncertainty there. And then, third, we're waiting to see when we will be able to recognize our revenue on the FIFA Online 3 in China with our partner Tencent or some contractual obligations that need to be met. And we don't know that will be met in the fourth quarter or in the first quarter. And so those uncertainties stopped us from flowing all $150 million through but what we did is flow through essentially the operating income benefit of our really flow through the entire EPS in the quarter.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our final question will come from Neil Doshi from CRT Capital.
componenttext: Our final question will come from Neil Doshi from CRT Capital.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Rob on the call for Neil. I just want to quickly ask on the nice marketing efficiency that you shared in the quarter. I think you maybe just give us a little bit more color on how much of that is due to or how you're thinking about how much of tha
componenttext: This is Rob on the call for Neil. I just want to quickly ask on the nice marketing efficiency that you shared in the quarter. I think you maybe just give us a little bit more color on how much of that is due to or how you're thinking about how much of that is due to improvements in game quality versus a structural shift to live services versus changes in marketing tactics?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rob, to answer question, all of the above. It's also great to have the title with the quality of Dragon Age: Inquisition. That's not only a great marketing, but all organically grew with the quality of the title and the ability for it to be able to get pi
componenttext: Rob, to answer question, all of the above. It's also great to have the title with the quality of Dragon Age: Inquisition. That's not only a great marketing, but all organically grew with the quality of the title and the ability for it to be able to get picked up of irony by gamers through then passed on to their recommendation to fellow gamers is something that we see. Secondarily, yes, we've been talking for 2, 3 years now about increased systems and efficiency that we're applying as a company towards the way that we communicate with our gamers. And you're seeing, you're seeing that in every single quarter. We should continue to ratchet down our expenses without revenues driving and without our efficiency increasing in the way that we communicate directly with our de minimis. We track metrics that are based on demand into the purchase. Aided awareness, those continue to grow across all of our franchises. And our ability to track our consumers on a day-to-day basis, rather than simply launch with big TV campaign to, which may have been what we've done many years ago, you're seeing the resulting efficiencies and the result of the marketing spend as a percentage in that revenue. And that will continue.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's one more dynamic, I would just add to that. and Peter's right in all fronts. The other dynamic, of course, is happening is by virtue of our live services in the ongoing engagement with our players. We are now more connected with our player based t
componenttext: There's one more dynamic, I would just add to that. and Peter's right in all fronts. The other dynamic, of course, is happening is by virtue of our live services in the ongoing engagement with our players. We are now more connected with our player based too much, much longer. And so the need to go out and kind of re-recruit players we may have had a disconnected or disengagement with is something that we're not having to encounter the same rate that we maybe did 2, 3 years ago. So there's ongoing shift to a live services of philosophy. It's not just helping us in terms of the ability to deliver amazing experiences to our players, but also it's keeping us connected with them so that we can ensure that they know about the latest great experiences that we have.
