headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jean. Good welcome to EA's Fiscal 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; Blake Jorgensen, our CFO; Frank Gibeau, our EVP of Mobile; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A porti
componenttext:
Thank you, Jean. Good welcome to EA's Fiscal 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; Blake Jorgensen, our CFO; Frank Gibeau, our EVP of Mobile; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared remarks. After the call, we will post our prepared remarks and audio replay of this call and the transcript. A couple of quick notes on the calendar. The date of our next earnings report will be Thursday, July 30 and our E3 Press Conference at 1 P.M. Pacific Time on Monday, June 15. 
This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events and results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. Electronic Arts makes these statements as of May 5, 2015, and disclaims any duty to update them.  
During this call, unless otherwise stated, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, as a substitute for, or superior to our GAAP results. We encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year, unless otherwise dated. Now, I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris, and thanks, everyone for joining us today. FY '15 was an exceptional year for Electronic Arts, with a clear focus on putting our players first, we delivered new experiences that were award winners, global bestsellers and breakout hits. Our
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris, and thanks, everyone for joining us today. FY '15 was an exceptional year for Electronic Arts, with a clear focus on putting our players first, we delivered new experiences that were award winners, global bestsellers and breakout hits. Our large services for franchises like Battlefield, FIFA, Madden NFL and The Sims are thriving. The communities in our mobile title continue to grow and through constant dialogue, we are forging deeper relationships with our players. We've broaden our portfolio on key platforms, introduce new service models and delivered quality through stable, scalable and individual experiences. All of this contributed to outstanding player engagement in EA experiences across console, PC and mobile in FY '15. Our financial results were consistently strong throughout the year. Revenue and EPS were above our guidance for the full fiscal year and we have reached an all-time high in operating cash flow. EA today is performing with focus and efficiency and we're leaning into our strength to deliver great experience into a growing and diverse audience of players around the world. 
Dragon Age: Inquisition and Battlefield Hardline are both terrific examples of the focus we have today. Moving launch date is never easy but we are committed to making the hard decision that will benefit our players. With Dragon Age: Inquisition, both extra few weeks of polish allowed BioWare to deliver  a truly epic new experience. Not only did it win dozens of game of the year awards, more importantly, our players gave it the highest form of praise, with nearly 200 million hours of Dragon Age: Inquisition played as of to-date. Additional team open up to player feedback earlier and more than ever before while developing Battlefield Hardline and the input from our community was a catalyst of great innovation. With the added development on, Battlefield Hardline delivered a complete package for different types of play, strategy based, battle field game play that our fans love, fast and fun new multiplayer mode like Hotwire, as well as a deep story driven single player campaign. We're very happy with how well the game has sold to-date and more importantly, that we brought many new fans into the Battlefield universe. 
Meanwhile, EA Sports had one of its best performance ever. Nearly 6 months after launch FIFA '15 remains a top 5 title in the Western world with more than 80 million matches on average every day in Q4. Game play hours of Madden NFL '15 were up nearly 30% for the quarter over last year and the hours played in Madden NFL Ultimate Team in the quarter increase a massive 97% year-over-year. Passionate sports fans are spending more time in our games today and engaging in our ultimate team mode which is extends the fun long after the season is over. We continue to see major growth in player engagement with our live services and offerings across all platforms. Our investment in Battlefield 4 brought great stability to the experience and allowed us to acquire a learning to ensure that Battlefield Hardline was stable and scalable at launch and beyond. We now have 2 Battlefield experiences with large highly engaged audiences and both received good expansion pack in the coming months. Other services are showing strong momentum with players, as well. Monthly engagement levels on Origin are up significantly over the previous year and the subscriber base that EA access continues to grow as we learn more about the innovative new delivery model on [indiscernible]. For players on smartphones and tablets, we built a strong foundation of key titles and now, we're adding to it. Players are going deeper into SimCity Builder logging more than 2.4 billion game sessions in Q4, and Madden NFL Mobile continues to capture more sports gamers with game play up 25% over the previous quarter. But perhaps the greatest example of our core strength in mobile is on the experiences that will provide use of entertainment is The Simpsons: Tapped Out. Nearly 3 years after launched, The Simpsons: Tapped Out average more than 16 million monthly players throughout FY '15. We are building some extra momentum in our mobile business and we're excited to launch new Minions and Star Wars experience later this year. 
In FY '15, we captured hundreds of millions of players with new RPG, sports, shooter, simulation and casual experiences across console, PC and mobile devices. Now, as we look ahead at the opportunities ahead of our as in FY '16 we are position to build relationships with millions more to entirely new experiences, as well as new games in our major franchises. Just 3 weeks ago, the world got its latest look at Star Wars Battlefront from Studio. The reaction has been powerful. Our Star Wars Battlefront trailer has been watched more than 29 million times to date across social platforms. Brought to life through an unprecedented partnership with Disney and Lucas Films, Star Wars Battlefront will immerse players  into the Star Wars universe like never before. The power of our thrust bite engine technology enabled us to deliver intricately detailed visuals and a completely offsetting environment for players to live out their Star Wars fantasy. Anticipation is now building for the launch of Star Wars Battlefront in November and we're excited to be part of one of the biggest global culture evidence of the year with the return of Star Wars. We look forward to showing more of Star Wars Battlefront in just a few weeks. 
In addition to Star Wars Battlefront, we will leverage the breath of our IP to reach a wider audience of players across multiple genres and platforms in FY '16. EA Sports will excite fans throughout the summer and fall with the latest releases of Rory McIlroy PGA Tour, Madden NFL, FIFA, NHL and NBA Live, including industry-leading gameplay, compelling new features and fresh ultimate experiences. FY '16 will see the return of Need For Speed as we introduce a new console experience as well a new mobile game. Maxes will continue to deliver great new content for The Sims 4, including another expansion pack, multiple game pack and additional game update for the growing Sims 4 community. After Plants vs. Zombies Garden Wars became a sensation last year with console players young and old,we will be returning to the Plants vs. Zombies universe with a bigger and bolder new console experience in FY '16 that will share more [indiscernible]. Minions Paradise, our first game with a popular franchise in partnership with Illumination Entertainment will be one of at least 5 new EA mobile titles this year. In spring 2016, [indiscernible] is set to revolutionized the action/adventure genre with its stunning first person gameplay. And of course, we'll continue to bring new content to our communities in Battlefield Hardline, Battlefield Fall, Dragon Age: Inquisition, Star Wars: The Old Republic, our EA Sports title and EA mobile games. Our large services will continue to give these experiences fresh and fun for players throughout the year. Across the world today, more people are playing games and spending more time playing games than ever before. The audience is wider and more diverse than we have ever known. Games are truly becoming the best form of entertainment and EA is well-positioned to benefit. Building relationships with new players and strengthening existing ones through meaningful engagement is at the core of our objective as a company.  We continue to invest in our digital platform, infrastructure, security, large service systems and community engagements to scale of the needs of the growing global player base that holds games as a vital and intrinsic part of their lives. FY '15 will commence as formative year for EA as we put our players first, delivering high potential services and drove great speed in the business. I'll now turn the call over to Blake for a deeper look at our Q4 financial performance and a view into the year ahead.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. As Andrew mentioned, we had another great quarter and a phenomenal 12 months. Before going into details, I'd like to step back and consider the journey we've been on for the last couple of years. When we first started talking about improvi
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. As Andrew mentioned, we had another great quarter and a phenomenal 12 months. Before going into details, I'd like to step back and consider the journey we've been on for the last couple of years. When we first started talking about improving the performance of Electronic Arts, I suggested that it would take 3 years to double our non-GAAP operating margins from 10% to 20%. We've exceeded that in 2 years. In fact, at nearly 25% our fiscal '15 operating margin is over 500 basis above our guidance at the beginning of the year and its highest point in over a decade.  We've dramatically increase our efficiency. Non-GAAP operating expenses were down full 10 percentage points from 56% of net revenue in fiscal '13 to just 46% in fiscal '15 and we've done so without adversely impacting our revenue or the effectiveness of our R&D or marketing. This year, we delivered the best Dragon Age of all-time, grew our sports franchises, expanded the core franchises Battlefield Hardline and announced new IP including Star Wars Battlefront. In addition, we continue to grow our digital live services and leverage our IT portfolio to establish a strong position on mobile platforms. Our core product catalog and digital live services are helping the company deliver more consistent, repeatable revenue and cash flow each year. These improvements have more than quadruple our free cash flow over the same period from 2000 -- $218 million in fiscal '13 and $972 million in fiscal '15 and driven a three-fold increase in non-GAAP diluted EPS from $0.84 a share to $2.51 a share. But there's plenty of road left to traveled on our journey to build both great games and shareholder value, most significantly, the digital transformation sweeping the whole industry is still in its infancy. This transformation presents the opportunity to continue to grow margin by increasing the proportion of full game downloads by providing extra content for games and by taking our IP to mobile platforms. Downloads of our games for our current generation consoles continue to increase. Meanwhile, our extra content and subscription strategy generated $1.3 billion in net revenue in fiscal '15 and continues to grow strongly. Finally, our mobile business at $524 million is now the third-largest in Western markets and the 8th largest worldwide and we anticipate continued healthy growth going forward. As well as driving gross margin improvement we continue to look for opportunities to better leverage our investments. For example, our digital platform strategy will help us better understand engage with gamers for more efficiently and standardized across studios across our titles and accelerate our innovation. Bottom line, we believe we can continue to grow non-GAAP EPS into the future. 
Moving to the fourth quarter results. EA's non-GAAP revenue was $896 million, which was $66 million above our guidance and $18 million below last year. The quarter's outperformance was driven by sales of Battlefield Hardline and the ongoing strength of our catalog titles. In addition, our mobile business continue to grow led by Sim City Builder, Madden NFL Mobile, The Sims Free Play and The Simpsons: Tapped Out. One note, because FIFA Online 3 was launched in China in April, we did not recognize any revenue in Q4. We expect to start recognizing revenue for this service in Q1 fiscal '16. EA's Q4 non-GAAP digital net revenue was $602 million. This resulted in a fiscal year digital revenue of more than $2.2 billion, about 52% of total revenue. Breaking down Q4's digital revenue into its key components highlights the performance of each business. First, extra content and PC free-to-play contributed $247 million, up 2% over the prior year. The growth of extra content slowed this quarter due to FX headwinds resulting from the fact that most of the FIFA Ultimate Team business is in Europe and from changes we made to reduce illegitimate coin selling in FIFA Ultimate Team. Nevertheless, for the year, FIFA Ultimate Team expanded over 40% and Madden NFL Ultimate Team more than doubled. Overall, Ultimate Team grew 53% on top of the prior year's 62% growth. We took staff during the quarter to reduce the trading of illegitimate FIFA Ultimate Team coins which had distorted the economy and made it difficult for many players build the team they wanted. We've made changes on game exploits and automated processes they used to generate those coins and taken steps to rebalance the game economy. However, some risks remain and we factor those into our Q1 and full year guidance. 
Second, our mobile business generated $150 million for the quarter, up 22% over prior year. Premium mobile only accounted for $9 million of the local revenue this quarter. Excluding premium, our ongoing mobile business grew 38% year-on-year. Third, download added $114 million to the quarter, flat year-on-year with strong sales of Battlefield Hardline, Dragon Age: Inquisition and The Sims 4, offsetting the falloff in Battlefield 4 and [indiscernible] sales. Our origin service from PC gamers have increase its monthly player engagement levels by 2/3 over the previous year and continues the strong program in end users. And finally, subscription, advertising and other digital revenue totaled $91 million, up $22 million or 32% over the same period last year, driven largely by Battlefield 4 premium. EA Access again outperformed and we expect its contribution to accelerate this year as we start to promote the service with Microsoft and continue to add titles to the EA access vault.  
Moving on to gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 75.4%, 140 basis points above our guidance due to the strength of Battlefield Hardline. It was down from 77.4% in Q4 of fiscal '14, primarily due to the strength of our sports titles. Operating expenses for the quarter were $513 million, up $10 million from last year and $2 million lower than our guidance. The year-on-year increase is primarily due to marketing expenses for Battlefield Hardline. The resulting non-GAAP diluted EPS for the quarter was $0.39 per share, 17% above our guidance. Net cash provided by operating activities for the quarter was $198 million compared to $281 million in the prior year, primarily due to the timing of titles. Operating cash flow for the full fiscal year gained its highest level in company history at $1.07 billion, a very significant increase over last year's cash flow of $712 million and above our twice revised guidance. Fiscal year '15 capital expenditure were $95 million, resulting in a free cash flow of $972 million. Our cash and short-term investments at the end of the quarter were $3.02 billion or $9.75 per share. Approximately 62% of this was held in the U.S. During the quarter, we repurchased 1.8 million shares of common stock at an average price of $53.44 per share. 
We far surpassed our expectations for the full fiscal year. On a non-GAAP basis, we exceeded our original revenue guidance by $219 million, gross margin by 250 basis points, operating cash flow by $267 million and EPS by $0.66 a share. The new EA is delivering more consistent revenue, increasing the proportion of high margin digital revenue and growing operating margins, earnings and cash flow. This has given the Board confidence to authorize a new $1 billion stock repurchase program. This new program has a 2 year time frame and replaces the remaining $356 million portion of our previous $750 million buyback program. It represents an expected return to shareholders of approximately 50% of forecasted free cash flow. 
Onto fiscal 2016 guidance. With regards to the market, we  expect the console transition to continue at a rapid pace and another 22 million units to be sold this calendar year, adding to the 27 million units in place at the end of calendar 2014. This is a much faster growth than in previous generation, illustrating how far the transition has already come, approximately 4 out of every 5 copies of Battlefield Hardline sold for consoles that were either Xbox One or PlayStation 4. In addition to the console growth, we are expecting our mobile franchise to benefit from the continued expansion of iOS and Android. We're anticipating the installed base to grow by  over $600 million to nearly 3 billion devices by the end of calendar 2015. On a constant currency basis, we expect non-GAAP revenue to increase approximately 8% to $4.65 billion. The anticipated strength is broad-based and driven by the launch of Star Wars Battlefront, the continued growth of our core sports titles and associated live services, the expansion of our mobile business and the addition of Need for Speed, Mirrors Edge and Plants vs. Zombies titles, as well as some other unannounced games. We expect foreign exchange rates will have an impact on our forecasted results. At our FY '16 guided exchange rates, we anticipated FX headwind of approximately $250 million, leading to our expectation for non-GAAP revenue of $4.4 billion. Volatility and exchange rates during the year may cause us to reconsider these assumptions and we'll update you on a quarterly basis. Non-GAAP gross margins is expected to rise about 50 basis points to 71.5%, driven by the increase in digital revenue. This forecast reflects gross margin pressure for product mix, since one of our major launches this year is Star Wars Battlefront, a royalty bearing title. As a reminder, the major non-sports titles last year were Battlefield Hardline, Dragon Age: Inquisition and The Sims 4, all of which are wholly owned IP. Although the dollars rise had a negative impact on revenue, it had a positive impact on expense, since about 46% of our R&D expenses is outside the U.S. This natural hedge is worth approximately $100 million in FY '16 and offset the increased investment for planning for new IP at our digital platform. As a result, we expect non-GAAP operating expenses of $1.98 billion, marginally down compared to fiscal '15. This will deliver an operating margin of approximately 26.5% and non-GAAP EPS of $2.75, up 10% year-on-year. This includes an average impact of $0.21 from FX and the benefit of $0.11 due to a change in tax rate. The strong growth of our business outside of the United States is having a long-term benefit to our corporate tax rate, such that we narrow view our long-term non-GAAP tax rate to be 22%, instead of 25%. Our non-GAAP EPS guidance does not factor in any share repurchases that may take place during the year. The earnings presentation on our Investor website contains more information about our exchange rate assumptions for the year. On a GAAP basis, guidances for net revenue of $4.25 billion, gross margin of 69.4% and EPS of $1.90. Segmenting the sales provides further insight into our key drivers of our full year non-GAAP revenue guidance. As a note, all of these revenue numbers assumed guidance exchange rates. Packaged goods and other revenues is forecasted to be approximately $1.85 billion, down 11%, driven by the continued shift to digital delivery. Digital revenue is forecasted to be nearly $2.55 billion, up 14%. 
Breaking down our digital revenue into 4 primary categories, we see the contributions from each group. Our mobile business is expected to grow approximately 25% as we broaden our revenue base through the launch of more free to download games based on our own IP, such as Need for Speed and licensed IT such as Star Wars and Minions, while continue to generate income from existing titles. In addition, the headwind remaining for the winding down of our premium mobile business is now very small. Revenue from full game downloads is anticipated to grow in line with last year's growth. Full game downloads on current generation consoles are now over 20% for a newly launched game and we're seeing higher percentages for our catalog titles. As a reminder, we count bundled games as physical sales, regardless of whether it is a disk or downloaded code in a box with the console. We've seen a dramatic increase in PC downloads since 2010 and we believe the same forces that drove this on PC are playing the latest generation of consoles. Extra content and free to downloads is expected to grow approximately 10% this year, driven by FIFA Online Tree and Ultimate Team. Our strongest markets for Ultimate Team are overseas, so this forecast is based on a significant effort FX headwind, as well as the changes we made to improve the FIFA Ultimate Team experience. Lastly, subscription revenue is expected to decline approximately 15% to 20% this year, driven by a falloff in Battlefield 4 premium revenue, partially offset by the growth in EA Assets and then by Battlefield Hardline premium revenue. GAAP operating expenses for the fiscal year are expected to be around $2.17 billion. 
Finally, cash flow will continue to be a key metric for us going forward. In fiscal 2016, we're forecasting operating cash flow of approximately $1.15 billion in capital expenses to be approximately $100 million, resulting in a free cash flow of $1.05 billion, versus $972 million in fiscal 2014. Focusing on Q1, our Q1 is seasonally the quietest of our fiscal year and although we have no major launches this quarter, we do anticipate strong catalog sales, particularly of FIFA '15 and Battlefield Hardline, which launched at the very end of Q4. GAAP revenue is expected to be $1.14 billion as compared to $1.2 billion in the prior year. GAAP diluted EPS is expected to be $1.14 as compared to $1.04 per share in the prior year. Non-GAAP revenue for the quarter is expected to be $640 million, a 17% decreased compared to last year's $775 million. The year-ago quarter benefited from more favorable exchange rate, Titanfall, the launch of the 2014 FIFA World Cup and UFC and from Battlefield 4 catalog. The decline is offset by Battlefield Hardline catalog but we are not planning any HD launches this quarter. Our revenue facing for FY '16 is different to the prior year with a much larger proportion in the back half due to our launch schedule. The expected savings of our revenues is in the earnings presentation posted to our website. Non-GAAP gross margin is forecasted to be approximately 74.5%. Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to be $475 million, $16 million higher compared to last year, driven by the extra week in the quarter, offset somewhat by more favorable exchange rates for overseas expenses. For the quarter, we expect non-GAAP diluted EPS to be $0.00 per share as compared to $0.19 per share last year. Looking further into the future, we remain focused on driving our business model and improving profitability. We will continue to leverage one of the core strengths of our business, the reoccurring revenue generated by our annualized titles, live services and ongoing mobile businesses. While not guarantee, this revenue is highly dependable and accounts for 60% to 70% of our total revenue. For the next few years, we expect further improvements in gross margin on the order of 100 basis points a year through growing our digital business. In addition, we will continue to invest in new and existing IP and a new technology infrastructure to support our growing live services business. In marketing, we will continue to increase personalization and customization and leverage our player network to further improve efficiency and impact. These efforts will help us move operating margins from the mid-20s to the high 20s and continue to grow our earnings and cash flow balance. 
In conclusion, fiscal '15, we made some considerable progress on our journey. We were able to massively grow earnings and cash generation and we have built a solid and consistent business with a strong operational foundation that enables us to capitalize on the shift to digital content, the console cycle and the growth of mobile. Now, I'll turn the call back to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. We are entering a new global age for games with a growing audience spend more time playing games across more platforms than ever before. New consoles are being adopted faster than the last generation, mobile continues its global expansion,
componenttext: Thanks, Blake. We are entering a new global age for games with a growing audience spend more time playing games across more platforms than ever before. New consoles are being adopted faster than the last generation, mobile continues its global expansion, new delivery and business models are poised to breakthrough on consoles and PC and there's huge innovation happening in gaming experiences across every Platform. players are essential in this era and our focus on building long-lasting relationships. As humans, we all need entertainment. For our players, we are delivering the best form of entertainment, through amazing new games, dynamic and enduring live services, vibrant communities and meaningful dialogue, we are enabling their passion for inspiration, immersion, competition, social connection and fun. The passion we have for that opportunity to leave this new age of gaming built around our global players is what will drive us in fiscal year '16 and beyond. With that, obviously, Blake, Peter, Frank and I are here for your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Colin Sebastian of Robert Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Colin Sebastian of Robert Baird.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first, maybe for Blake, with all the progress and success on data of managing expenses, I can only imagine that there are some pressure to invest more given all the growth opportunity. Can you talk a little bit about the ability to keep expenses r
componenttext: I guess first, maybe for Blake, with all the progress and success on data of managing expenses, I can only imagine that there are some pressure to invest more given all the growth opportunity. Can you talk a little bit about the ability to keep expenses roughly flat adjusting for the FX impact? And is that a realistic expectation in the future years. And then secondly, maybe Peter could add some color the specific impact you're seeing on Ultimate Team on FIFA with the pricing changes on the transfer market research.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so first question on our guidance for OpEx. We're actually saying in the script, roughly $100 million of investment that we're making. It's flat because of the obviously, the FX impact on our international phase investments. I think we're making subs
componenttext: Yes, so first question on our guidance for OpEx. We're actually saying in the script, roughly $100 million of investment that we're making. It's flat because of the obviously, the FX impact on our international phase investments. I think we're making substantial investments in new IP, in mobile IP, in our game engine to try to continue to expand the cross from multiple products and in our underlying infrastructure. We're continuing to focus on making marketing more efficient and effective by leveraging our digital connection with our consumers and that will benefit us in our marketing expenses. But I guarantee we'll continue to support our brands in a fairly healthy way. I think we're making the right investments going forward and we'll continue to help drive the top line of the business and the effectiveness of our product.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Colin, it's Peter. And just on Ultimate Team, as Blake said in his commentary, FIFA Ultimate Team expanded 40% and Madden NFL Ultimate Team more than doubled. So overall, Ultimate Team grew 53% and that's on top of the previous year, 62%. As you know, we'
componenttext: Colin, it's Peter. And just on Ultimate Team, as Blake said in his commentary, FIFA Ultimate Team expanded 40% and Madden NFL Ultimate Team more than doubled. So overall, Ultimate Team grew 53% and that's on top of the previous year, 62%. As you know, we're aware, you track it and there will be difference in measures and place outlined by both Andrew and Blake to look at some of the more nefarious actions that were going on, we continue to monitor that, keep very close eye on what's going on, trying to balance the economy, keep some of the coin sellers out but we have great optimism that our growth in Ultimate Team will continue going forward in FY '16 and beyond.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, a lot of anticipation in the Star Wars. Can you give us any thoughts on how you incorporated that into your guidance and how it might affect the gross profit and kind of is there going to be a marketing benefit from that title given all the hyp
componenttext: Obviously, a lot of anticipation in the Star Wars. Can you give us any thoughts on how you incorporated that into your guidance and how it might affect the gross profit and kind of is there going to be a marketing benefit from that title given all the hyper movie?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we certainly hope that we can leverage a lot of the hype. We certainly have done that so far. We've got a great partner in Disney and Lucas Films on that. They're very excited for our title as well. For us, we're thinking about it with kind of 2 book
componenttext: Yes, we certainly hope that we can leverage a lot of the hype. We certainly have done that so far. We've got a great partner in Disney and Lucas Films on that. They're very excited for our title as well. For us, we're thinking about it with kind of 2 bookends, right? 1 book end is the historical battlefront which is roughly 9 million units. The other book end is our core first-person shooter franchise of Battlefield which typically does around 15 million units. So I think in our guidance we can roughly put in there roughly 9 million to 10 million units for the title which we believe some upsides obviously if things go well. It is Gen 4 only in PC and so that needs to get factored into people's thinking but it is very exciting title. It will put, as we said in the script some pressure on the gross margin in the quarter. We've been trying to target 100 basis points of gross margin improvement and this year we're forecasting roughly 50 basis points. And much of that is due to the fact that there's a loyalty on that to Disney and at a level of 10 million units, that's a fairly large pressure on gross. So that's -- we're very optimistic and excited about this title and obviously, the markets been the same way. The feedback we've seen from recently, the Disney celebration where we showed the title for the first time, we're obviously showing more, so if you get a chance appreciate the depth and the excitement around that.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen Ju of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen Ju of Crdit Suisse.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Andrew or Peter, some of your competitors showed off what I thought was pretty interesting piece of technology which allows streaming of game content from the either the smartphone or the table onto the TV. So I mean that obviously creates some interestin
componenttext: Andrew or Peter, some of your competitors showed off what I thought was pretty interesting piece of technology which allows streaming of game content from the either the smartphone or the table onto the TV. So I mean that obviously creates some interesting opportunities for you as a publisher to take stuff off the console. So is this an area of focus for you right now or should we expect some of your less graphics intense titles should concurrently with the console release at least some point in the future? And secondarily, how much data are you collecting from all of your users, just broadly and where do you think you are in terms of using that data to influence your content development?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'll take that. 2 great questions. 1 relates to streaming. Streaming as a technology is still in its infancy I would say. Certainly, we have a few integration efforts going on around the company. Let's see how best we can benefit from that. But as y
componenttext: Okay. I'll take that. 2 great questions. 1 relates to streaming. Streaming as a technology is still in its infancy I would say. Certainly, we have a few integration efforts going on around the company. Let's see how best we can benefit from that. But as you think about our core objective which is to build more relationships with more players across more platforms around the world, streaming certainly represents an opportunity for us. A lot of work to go there in order to deliver the kind of experiences we believe our players want to play but certainly we have going on. As it relates to data collection, we are collecting, I heard, 1 stat we collect more data on a daily basis than the combined U.S. Library of Congress, which as you can imagine is a lot of data. At a more core level, what we're trying to understand better than our players is how engagement works, how engagement works were playing engagement with them on more than 1 platform, how engagement works where a player plays more than 1 franchise and the effective engagement over the long-term as it relates to the likelihood that a player will continue and buy the next version of a title provided we can keep them playing overtime. So there's a lot in our data right now as it relates to our players. We are using that data 1, to build better games and 2, to deliver more enhanced and extended and engaging experience over time to keep them playing and entertained for longer.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Merwin with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Merwin with Barclays.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just in the context of your guidance for' 16, Blake, I think you talk about 10% growth for the extra content business and I think a lot of that coming from people online in China. Can you quantify on what you're expecting in terms of dollars for FIFA O
componenttext: So just in the context of your guidance for' 16, Blake, I think you talk about 10% growth for the extra content business and I think a lot of that coming from people online in China. Can you quantify on what you're expecting in terms of dollars for FIFA Online in China or maybe ask another way,  do you think this could be bigger than FIFA online in Korea? And then secondly, on the mobile business, I don't know if you can give out a margin for that business but are you seeing stability in that margin or even improvement as you more branded IP. I imagined that relative to competitors, you might even have lower sales in marketing cost for mobile given that you are leveraging brand IP that as a build an audience and imagine that would lower the cost of customer acquisition.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me start on FIFA Online through China and I'll have Frank address the local economics. On FIFA 3 on China as we said we did not recognize any revenue in Q3 for that. We will start recognizing revenue in Q1 this quarter, which will include the
componenttext: Yes. So let me start on FIFA Online through China and I'll have Frank address the local economics. On FIFA 3 on China as we said we did not recognize any revenue in Q3 for that. We will start recognizing revenue in Q1 this quarter, which will include the revenues that we've generated in last year for that title, roughly be around $40 million this quarter. I think going forward, for your model, I probably focus on $10 million to $15 million a quarter and as that business grows, we'll keep you updated. We're very optimistic about it. Tencent has been very public around their optimism. But we remind people it's taken us 3 to 4 years to grow Korea's awareness today and Korea is a more fluent market than China right now. So it's probably going to take some time. Also software is much more prevalent in Korea than it is in China but it's growing faster in China. So we hope to follow that. So it's a longer story for us, we think but I think there's a lot of potential and everything is going very well. Frank, on the mobile?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the question on mobile, I'll say, when we look at how Electronic Arts is constructing its mobile business there's a couple of key competitive advantages that we're trying to harness. And the first is we have the broadest and more diverse and powerful
componenttext: Yes, the question on mobile, I'll say, when we look at how Electronic Arts is constructing its mobile business there's a couple of key competitive advantages that we're trying to harness. And the first is we have the broadest and more diverse and powerful portfolio of brands in the business and that translates into very strong organic acquisition advantages. So pound for pound, people have heard of Sim City, The Sims, products like FIFA, Madden and organically they install it at very high rates. If you look at how SimCity did over the break. We were generating tens of millions of installs without really spending any money in paid acquisition. That's also combined with a really powerful network that we're designing. So it allows us to cross promote and understand based on telemetry and data, what our gamers doing at any given time and what's the right message at the right time and what are the right games that we put in front of them that might interest them. So the combination of a profound organic acquisition power coming from brand power and a network effect, we believe will allow us to from a long-term standpoint, keep marketing and sales at a percentage of revenue very low. Very low certainly relative to other mobile game companies. And as we look to grow the business, we'll continue to harness those advantages.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Arvind Bhatia of Sterne Agee CRT.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones. Just going back to the FIFA Online pre-China question. We got the revenue guidance. I would assume that most of that revenue comes at pretty full margin. Wondering if you could maybe comment on that? And then you touch on EA Access
componenttext: A couple of quick ones. Just going back to the FIFA Online pre-China question. We got the revenue guidance. I would assume that most of that revenue comes at pretty full margin. Wondering if you could maybe comment on that? And then you touch on EA Access. Wondering if you can maybe elaborate a little bit more, how we should think about the adoption rates right now? What are some of the puts and takes there? And then lastly, Andrew would love to get your views on the overall market -- console market in particular, over the next couple of years. We see your breakdown of the physical versus digital revenue. Just wondering how you think about the progression over the next couple of years.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on FIFA online 3, we don't disclose obviously, the profitability of the individual lines of the business but what you should assume there is Tencent is essentially delivering the product and doing much of the marketing and the local market. We're doing
componenttext: So on FIFA online 3, we don't disclose obviously, the profitability of the individual lines of the business but what you should assume there is Tencent is essentially delivering the product and doing much of the marketing and the local market. We're doing the product development and helping Tencent on any issues around hosting and delivering the product. So we obviously have broad development cost. We don't have some of the marketing costs that you see on our normal business. So you should assume there's good profit margins but that's as far as I can go on that. On the EA Access, we're extremely pleased with the growth of EA Access. As i said on the call, we haven't really started to promote that with Microsoft, we will this summer. We've now added, we've got 12 titles in the vault and that's why we feel like it's a great time to start to promote it because much of the value is around those titles in the vault. The subscriber base continues to grow. It's still not a meaningful part of our financials and thus we're not calling out the actual numbers of the staff but we will do that in the future as we see how it grows. But overall, we're very interested in it and we're learning a great deal from the service around players interest and subscription model and where they get the most value out of the service. I want Andrew to touched on the last 1 about console.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Overall, we're very happy with the speed of which this console generation is being taken up by players, as we talked about in prepared notes, it's much faster than last generation and we would expect close 50 million console by the end of the year and tha
componenttext: Overall, we're very happy with the speed of which this console generation is being taken up by players, as we talked about in prepared notes, it's much faster than last generation and we would expect close 50 million console by the end of the year and that's a meaningful installed base for us to build games for and the level of engagement we're seeing on a per game basis is also very, very high with people engaging in a lot of services that we're building around those games for much, much longer than before. As we think about retail versus full game downloads, certainly, we've seen growth in that area. It's very varies from geography to platform but on a Gen 4 game like Battlefield Hardline in the West, we're seeing nearly 20% numbers and we would expect that growth to continue. We've seen a dramatic increase in PC downloads in 2010 and we believe the same forces that drove this in PC are at play on this latest generation of consoles. And as bandwidth increases, lower-cost storage increases, we would expect continued growth in this area.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We always give this stat on every call. We're up 51% over the same period in Gen 4 versus Gen 3. So 17 months since launch, the installed base of Gen 4 console is now up 51% versus the same period for Gen 3.
componenttext: We always give this stat on every call. We're up 51% over the same period in Gen 4 versus Gen 3. So 17 months since launch, the installed base of Gen 4 console is now up 51% versus the same period for Gen 3.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: Just follow-on regarding the full games download. You mentioned 20% gives like Battlefield. Are you trying to kind of accelerate that as fast as you can because it's better margin? Or are there reasons to kind of take it slowly, I guess in other words are theres risks to a rapid transition to downloads or you're just putting the pedal down on kind of pushing that as fast as you can? And then secondly, regarding the pipeline, we notice that Titanfall is not in your announced title slate. Does that mean it won't ship in fiscal '16 or does that mean that it may or may not ship in the year but would currently be an unannounced title if it were a fiscal '16 launch?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first on full game downloads, we're essentially allowing the consumer to vote. We are we would like the consumer to consume games where they want to consumed and if that's in full game download or about retail, we want to be there. We've got great part
componenttext: So first on full game downloads, we're essentially allowing the consumer to vote. We are we would like the consumer to consume games where they want to consumed and if that's in full game download or about retail, we want to be there. We've got great partners in retail, GameStop target Wal-Mart, Gain, others are very powerful and helpful to us. so you want to make sure we're delivering the experience in the way that consumers would like. Obviously, it's better economically for us longer term to do digital and we're focused on all the digital content not just for games. And we see that's that the direction the industry is going but we're not trying to do something unnatural to put this on one way or the other. In terms of folkways at assume that it's not in Cisco System. It's more likely in school 17 and the title of that we brought pretty clear is the 1 following the title slate. So your assumptions should be double streamed.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015

componenttext: So just want to go back to FIFA. You guys talk about a lot of the puts and takes that will contribute to result in fiscal '16. You take a step back and you're comping against the World Cup last year below what are your expectations for the franchise, maybe on a constant currency basis or a headline number? And then separately, as it relates to Star Wars, you mentioned that you're going to be publishing a Gen 4 only. Is that a strategy you intend to imply across all other franchises going forward?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Drew on FIFA, we expect continued growth of that franchise. Obviously, the size that franchise is now. A lot large number makes big growth numbers difficult but we continually year in and year out been able to grow FIFA by improving the quality of
componenttext: Yes, so Drew on FIFA, we expect continued growth of that franchise. Obviously, the size that franchise is now. A lot large number makes big growth numbers difficult but we continually year in and year out been able to grow FIFA by improving the quality of the game, by adding extra additional services around the game like Ultimate Team and driving it into new geographies around the world. The popularity of football in America continues to grow and that's been fueling the growth of the products here in the U.S. even though it's always been very strong internationally and we think will continue to see that. So we are very optimistic about the FIFA. You to see bit that continue to see upside growth and that's what and our forecast. Your second question was before so as far as Star Wars is concerned.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, things. So we will see a slow movement away from Gen 3. As a reminder, we've been making Gen 2 also bans up until the last year or so. So for some of our bigger prejudices of our sport franchise, we will continue to make Gen 3. But we are making some
componenttext: Yes, things. So we will see a slow movement away from Gen 3. As a reminder, we've been making Gen 2 also bans up until the last year or so. So for some of our bigger prejudices of our sport franchise, we will continue to make Gen 3. But we are making some decisions on new franchise that entitles carryforward partially because of the power of the platform. Those for exceptional gameplay and incredible graphics. And for something like Star Wars, we wanted to make sure that we provide the highest level of quality for the game experience that we can do that only engine for PC.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, May 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, I would now like to turn the call how you do the math. I was not implying at all what '17 cash was going to be done progress good to try to help people understand what you're thinking about return of capital. The goal would be if we were to continue
componenttext: Okay, I would now like to turn the call how you do the math. I was not implying at all what '17 cash was going to be done progress good to try to help people understand what you're thinking about return of capital. The goal would be if we were to continue to be able to increase capital over time, we will continue to do increase our buybacks overtime. So in that again about that is for the 2-year program and you can see we start considering that program a year ago and replace that with a new 2-year program this year. Not predicting what that's going to be for the future but think about it more like a progression of the time overs as any guidance around fiscal '17. So we're optimistic about '16 and '17. So that piece, the FIFA Online Tree's free-to-play PC game, which means much like in Ultimate Team, you monetize based on collecting and trading players and playing with those players. You don't have someone it but I ask you to play the game for free but like all 3 the play games to build a better team, and get farther ahead of the game so even a guess your friend, you will possibly monetize the bill that team. So revenue recognition is issue was simply a one-time issue for us and that was we were waiting for the form of rollout of the game in China with our partner, Tencent. And that occurred in early April and that's the ability to start to recognize revenue. Did not want to recognize revenue until the game is fully functional, fully rolled out, move from soft beta to hard beta to full rollout and had all of the features available for gameplay. And that's why we've now start to recognized but we should not going forward on that.
