headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kaye. Welcome to EA's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SE
componenttext:
Thank you, Kaye. Welcome to EA's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared remarks. Lastly, after the call, we will post our prepared remarks and  audio replay of this call and the transcript. A quick calendar note. Our Q2 earnings call is scheduled for Thursday, October 29.  
This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events and results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. 
Electronic Arts makes these statements as of today July 30, 2015, and disclaims any duty to update them. 
During this call, unless otherwise stated, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, as a substitute for, or superior to our GAAP results. We encourage  investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Q1 was a great start to fiscal year 2016 as we continue our journey to put our players first and deliver amazing entertainment experience following. We're building deeper connections with the players in our games and live services there is
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Q1 was a great start to fiscal year 2016 as we continue our journey to put our players first and deliver amazing entertainment experience following. We're building deeper connections with the players in our games and live services there is tremendous resentment for upcoming titles and we see profound new energy in our industry. 
Our Q1 results were excellent, with revenue margins and earnings above our guidance. Our top games and large services, including EA SPORTS FIFA 15, Battlefield Hardline, The Sims 4, are engaging players around the world with fresh new experiences. We see continued strength in our mobile trials with new games coming later this year. EA is executing well against our plans for FY '16. And with ongoing strength in our digital business and growing anticipation for upcoming titles, we are raising our full year guidance today to reflect momentum across the portfolio. 
Our industry is hitting a powerful stride as we advance further into the new global era for games. The Xbox One and PlayStation 4 installed base continues to grow and show great strength, driving well beyond adoption rates of previous generation devices. 
The opportunities in mobile, as well as new service and delivery models, are opening up new ways to bring players into our games than ever before. At the E3 conference in Germany, the appetite for great new games was for you. Players on all platforms are ready for new experiences that capture the imagination with creativity, innovation and breakthrough gameplay. 
EA is in a strong position to deliver. We had an outstanding E3 this year sure taking 15 to our players, media and partners. Throughout the event, our partnership with Disney and Lucasfilm was in full view. Star Wars Battlefront stunned audiences with a magnitude and really some of it being play. We revealed a new expansion for Star Wars expression and announced the new Star Wars mobile game. We unveiled new expenses for original IP with Andromeda, Plants vs. Zombies Garden Warfare 2 and surprised with the unexpected charm of Unravel. 
We celebrated the return of Need for Speed, captivated players with the authenticity of our sports games and detail the gameplay innovation in Mirror's Edge: Catalyst. At 10 days, we're able to go hands-on with all of these years titles in our E3 business. 
Most importantly, through content and social conversation, we brought the E3 experience to players around the world. Millions of viewers joined this team of our light event and our titles were mentioned more than 500 times per minute on social media during the week of E3. Trailers, gameplay and live streams of targets were viewed over 53 million times throughout E3 and Star Wars Battlefront alone generated 22 million views on social platforms, a most popular content ever at E3. It was tremendous to see such positive reaction from players and feel the excitement level for our games continuing to build. 
We're looking forward to sharing more at games in just a few days. 
In addition to our upcoming games, our launch service today are ecosystems of ever-changing content for our players. Battlefield 4 and Battlefield Hardline players load a combined 170 million online gameplay hours in Q1 and will be bringing new expansion perhaps in both experiences in the coming months. 
The Sims 4 play community continues to grow and engage deeply with the game as we deliver more updating content. And we saw gameplay hours in our mobile hit, The Sims FreePlay increased 85% year-over-year. 
In addition, our EA SPORTS ultimate team modes average of the 2 million players per day in Q1, up nearly 20% year-over-year. Amazing and created new experiences, dynamic-wide services and deeply engaged communities built on strong and meaningful relationships with our players. These are the building blocks of our long-term strategy for Electronic Arts. 
Throughout key franchises as well as experiences with new and original IP, we have the ability to rich more players than ever. EA Access Origin and our new extremity games trailer are bringing more player games to compete, connect and feel their passion for games. 
And with our digital infrastructure, analytics and large services, we are evolving and personalizing experience for each players, and exploring how first game services and create additional value for everyone. 
After a strong first quarter, the stage is now set for us to deliver a slate and groundbreaking and is stunning new games through the remainder of FY '16. 
I'll now turn the call over to Blake for a deep look at our financials.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $693 million, which was $53 million or more than 8% above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 11% lower than prior years because we had no title on launches this quarter. And the year ago quarter included
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $693 million, which was $53 million or more than 8% above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 11% lower than prior years because we had no title on launches this quarter. And the year ago quarter included the launches of Titanfall for Xbox 360, EA SPORTS FIFA World Cup 2014 and EA SPORTS UFC. 
Our core business was strong. At a constant currency, this quarter's revenue would have been within 4% of last year's. 
As I discussed the results for the quarter, bear in mind that FX changes have had a dramatic impact on year-on-year comparisons. The euro, for example, fell nearly 20% against the dollar from the first quarter last year to this year's first quarter. 
In the first quarter, EA SPORTS, FIFA 15 Battlefield Hardline and The Sims 4 drove solid revenue and delivered excellent margins. This demonstrates the power of our deep catalog of popular IT, which delivers stable revenue throughout the year. The revenue and margin versus guidance were driven by better-than-expected performance from FIFA Ultimate Team and The Sims 4. 
Our non-GAAP digital net revenue for the quarter increased 10% year-over-year to $532 million, 77% from this quarter's revenue. The trailing 12-month digital net revenue was up 20% to $2.28 billion. 
Breaking down our digital revenue into its key components highlights the performance of each of these businesses this quarter. Extra content and freemium contributed $255 million, up 21% over the prior year. The principal driver of this growth was FIFA Online 3 in China. $31 million of the FIFA Online free revenue was deferred from previous quarter as noted in our last earnings call. 
Total Ultimate Team was down 6% year-on-year, but up 3% on a constant currency basis, even with the World Cup boosting FIFA Ultimate Team engagement levels last year. 
Mobile generated $122 million in the quarter. Digital extra contents and advertising was up 11% versus the prior year to $115 million, while premium mobile full game download revenue was just $7 million, down 56% compared to the prior year. 
We expect premium full game download revenue to be remain at this minimal level for the foreseeable future. 
Full game PC and console downloads generated $84 million of revenue, up 18% over the prior year. We continue to see the digital download increase as a percentage of full game sales, although this quarter was particularly high since our catalog titles typically ske more towards digital download than newly launched games. 
Subscriptions, advertising and other digital revenues contributed $71 million, down 11% from last year due to the natural decline in Battlefield 4 Premium revenue. EA Access is delivering strong sustained growth, and we continue to build this value of gamers as we add more games to the vault. 
Titanfall is now in the vault and Dragon Age Inquisition will join us at the end of the summer, bringing the total titles to 13. 
Moving on to gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 76.8%, an increase from last year's 70.2% and better than our guidance of 74.5%. 
Growth over the prior year was driven by product mix, the shift to digital and FIFA Online 3 in China. We exceeded guidance largely through better-than-expected performance from FIFA Ultimate Team and the continued success of The Sims 4, which delivers very high margins by virtue of being a PC title based on fully owned IP. 
Non-GAAP operating expenses for the quarter were $472 million, up $13 million or 3% year-on-year. The increase over last year was driven by R&D payroll tax expenses related to stock-based compensation, which is written with the stock price and by the extra week in the quarter. This is offset by FX and lower marketing costs as a result of no major launches this quarter. 
The resulting non-GAAP EPS was $0.15 a share, which is $0.15 better than guidance due to strong revenue and higher gross margin. 
As a reminder, this calculated at our new tax rate of 22%. 
Our cash and short-term investments at the end of the quarter were $2.88 billion or approximately $9.23 per share. 64% of this cash and short-term investment balance is held onshore. 
Net cash used by operating activities for the quarter was $71 million. On a trailing 12-month basis, operating cash flow was $992 million, a record for this period. 
During Q1, we repurchased 2.2 million shares on a cost of $132 million. Our $1 billion stock buyback program was initiated partly through Q1 in May 2015 and has a 2-year time frame. As of the end of the first quarter, there was $925 million left on the $1 billion plan as some of the stock repurchased during the quarter was bought into the old plan. Due to the strength of our business, we are increasing our full year guidance. 
For fiscal 2016, our non-GAAP guidance for revenue was up by $50 million to $4.45 billion and our non-GAAP EPS increases $0.10 to $2.85 per share. This results in an expected operating margin of 27%. 
It's still early in the year, and with Q1 representing less than 16% of expected full year revenues, we believe some continued conservatism is appropriate. 
A GAAP guidance becomes $4.3 billion in revenue and $1.98 of fully diluted EPS. Regarding cash flow for the year, we are reiterating our operating cash flow guidance for approximately $1.15 billion. Our capital expense forecast remains approximately $100 million, resulting in a free cash flow forecast of approximately $1.05 billion. 
Guidance for our second quarter is for non-GAAP net revenue to be $1.075 billion, 12% lower than last year's $1.22 billion. 
In this quarter, we're launching Madden NFL, FIFA, Rory McIlroy PGA Tour, NHL and NBA Live. While last year's Q2 saw the launches of our major sports data, it also included The Sims 4. 
In addition, FX present a year-on-year impact of around $100 million to Q2 revenue. 
Non-GAAP gross margin is forecasted to be 63%. Again, the main difference between this quarter and a year ago quarter is the launch of The Sims 4. We expect our Q2 non-GAAP operating expenses to be $510 million, up slightly year-on-year, driven by an increased investment in R&D and offset by FX and savings and marketing. This resulted in a non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.40 per share as compared to $0.73 per share last year. 
Our Q2 GAAP net revenue is expected to be $815 million as compared to $990 million in the prior year. GAAP loss per share is expected to be $0.58 as compared to $0.01 per share profit in the prior year. 
We're very pleased with our first quarter results. Our ability to reliably generate earnings even in the absence of major launches is a testament to the value of our broad IT portfolio, our catalog and our robust live services. 
Digital extra content and mobile continue to provide additional layers of consistent revenue. On top of this, player reactions are marquee titles at E3 gives us great confidence that our competitive position as we look forward into this year and beyond. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Andrew

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. We have a great deal ahead of us over the next 3 quarters as we prepare to deliver a range of new titles from our key franchises and original IP, as well as more new content supplies in our live services. We'll have 4 more yeast experience
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. We have a great deal ahead of us over the next 3 quarters as we prepare to deliver a range of new titles from our key franchises and original IP, as well as more new content supplies in our live services. We'll have 4 more yeast experience is launching through the summer and fall in each '16, FIFA 16 and NBA Live 16, all featuring engaging new modes and groundbreaking gameplay for our players. 
Need for Speed will go live in November and saying a loving and deep customization that we've shown so far. And of course, Star Wars Battlefront will launch on November 17. The excitement for this game continues to build. It took them 45 awards from E3, including Game of the Year for IBM and Best Online Multiplayer from the E3 Game Critics. We look forward to unveiling you dimensions of Star Wars Battlefront and letting players hands on NetSuite at games comp. 
We have more new experiences coming throughout the year. Our live services will continue to evolve with new content. We'll have some great new mobile games and we're excited to have a 3-year new in original IP titles launching in Q4. 
Looking further ahead, we're preparing more new games for our players. The reaction to our first look at E3 was incredibly positive. We have a new Battlefield experience coming in Q3 FY '17 and another new Star Wars project being led by the dynamic rated team of Raymond and Amy Henny. 
These are just a few of the new experiences in development across our studios today. 
From the creativity of our teams to the technologies we are building to the passion for play that we share with our players, we are pushing the boundaries for games in an effort to go with them the next amazing experience. Through our games among services we will immerse place in introducing saying gives a new character as to transfer them into a adventure to capture the imagination. 
In a new global age for games, where more time is spent playing than ever before, we are also building a future with relationships at the core. Through our network, we are connecting players with each other and are bringing experiences that are meaningful every time they play. 
I look forward to sharing more update on our progress in the quarters ahead. 
Now I'd like -- Peter and I are here for your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Chris Merwin from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Chris Merwin from Barclays.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just had one on gross margin. I think, Blake, you touched on some of this, but it's very impressive market that you posted. I'm just hoping if you could provide a little bit more detail on what in particular drove that through a combination of, I gue
componenttext: So I just had one on gross margin. I think, Blake, you touched on some of this, but it's very impressive market that you posted. I'm just hoping if you could provide a little bit more detail on what in particular drove that through a combination of, I guess, digital downloads, FIFA Online in China and wherever else. And then just secondly, in terms of Ultimate Team, I think you commented that it was up slightly on a constant currency basis but down on a reported basis. I know last quarter, it was illegal issue and I knew you're working to resolve that. Just curious where you stand as relates to that and then how we should be thinking about the most Ultimate Team for the rest of the year in the context of your extra content revenue?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first on gross margin. The gross margin -- couple of things to remember in just year-over-year comparisons. One, last year, both Titanfall and UFC our royalty bearing titles. So they have dampened last year's gross margin a little bit. But the re
componenttext: Sure. So first on gross margin. The gross margin -- couple of things to remember in just year-over-year comparisons. One, last year, both Titanfall and UFC our royalty bearing titles. So they have dampened last year's gross margin a little bit. But the real driver for us was the strength, as you noted FIFA Online 3, obviously, some of that deferred revenues are coming in at very nice gross margin. But second and probably more importantly, the strength of The Sims 4. And just to give people a reminder, last year, the sentence started a little slow growth into our thinking. We talked about that in our Q2 earnings. But the strength of The Sims franchises, the layering in our expansion packs that really fuel not just the expansion pack revenue, but bring people into the core game. And we were in a situation where many consumers were comparing the original Sims 4 game to the Sims 3 game with a long series of expansion packs. And as a now start to bring out expansion packs, they're starting to see the power of The Sims 4 gameplay and the excitement around it. And we sold more Sims 4 this quarter than we thought. And we think that trend will continue and we're very excited about it not just because of the franchises, but because of the power to the drive to the gross margin. And then last but not least as you saw the digital business as a whole with 77% of our total revenue, and that included a large amount of full game downloads, which obviously enhances margin, as well as all the other components of the digital business, which enhanced our gross margin. And that really helped the overall delivery relative to plan. Now in terms of FIFA Ultimate Team, and I encourage Peter or Andrew to jump in on this if they'd like. First, we saw, as you said Ultimate Team down slightly, but up on a constant currency basis. And a key reminder there is the comparison year-over-year was the FIFA Ultimate Team did extremely well in the first quarter last year because of the World Cup and all of the people playing associated with the World Cup and the World Cup modes that have in the game. We did see a better performance of FIFA Ultimate Team that we expected. As you remember in Q1, we -- our last call, Q4, excuse me, we did some warning that because the illegitimate coin selling we thought that we would see some slowdown in FIFA Ultimate Team mainly because the actions we take the standing. Much of that will be corrected in the new version of FIFA Ultimate Team that comes out with FIFA 16, and we're excited about that. And we don't see any change to our outlook for the overall extra content and Ultimate Team business in the future. And as you can see, we were surprised that we did better than expected on Ultimate Team in the quarter, which also helped drive margins. There's a lot of excitement about soccer in the world. The women's World Cup in Canada really drove huge amount of excitement in North America. We're seeing a greater amount of excitement across Asia. And we think that will continue to help drive both the FIFA product and Ultimate Team product over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: This is Ryan calling in for Justin. First question is on OpEx. You've done a good job of managing those expenses back several years, I think, you got a show some sequential growth there. Any color you can give on just where you are in terms of investing for the cycle and OpEx growth going forward? Second, Blake, can you just compare whether or not Unravel was included in your prior outlook and just either of the guidance increase this quarter due to on a nonstory new title of the products?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me hit OpEx for us. So OpEx -- the OpEx that we get guidance on as the start of the year obviously had a change in terms of the guidance. We have built into that OpEx, r&D investment and both console and mobile products, and that's why you're
componenttext: Sure. So let me hit OpEx for us. So OpEx -- the OpEx that we get guidance on as the start of the year obviously had a change in terms of the guidance. We have built into that OpEx, r&D investment and both console and mobile products, and that's why you're seeing a slight uptick. The OpEx of this quarter was driven primarily by the options or RFU exercises and the tax expenses associated with those. We didn't forecast the stock price to be as high as it turned out to be was a bit higher than we expected. Still, obviously, within our guidance and we're comfortable with our full year guidance on OpEx. We're continuing to try to be extremely efficient in R&D and continue to try to build better system to drive marketing expenses around the great digital connection we have with our users, our gamers and consumers out there. And you'll hopefully see continued benefit to that over time. In terms of the guidance and products, Unravel was in the original guidance. I don't think the expectations around the love for Yarny himself was quite built into our guidance. And we were pleasantly surprised at E3 about how popular he was. But it's still a fairly small [indiscernible]  added any products our guidance that was not the reason that we raised the number the number was raised primarily due to the positive reception we saw across all of our products and the strength of the industry, as Andrew mentioned, the excitement we've seen our own console gaming and the continued popularity of both Xbox and PlayStation and the strength of that going forward. So that is really the driver to our rate guidance.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay and then 1 quick follow-up if I could on digital and the mobile. The pretty sharp fall off, but it looks like the smartphone portion that mobile zooming well. Can you help us with the phasing of mobile throughout the year or any products that we shou
componenttext: Okay and then 1 quick follow-up if I could on digital and the mobile. The pretty sharp fall off, but it looks like the smartphone portion that mobile zooming well. Can you help us with the phasing of mobile throughout the year or any products that we should be aware of that come out in the mobile in the near term?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we talked about a couple of key products that are coming out in the back cover the year. I can't give you exact date. We test our mobile products extensively, and so it's often hard to be able to get exactly when the launch date going to be. Clearly
componenttext: Well, we talked about a couple of key products that are coming out in the back cover the year. I can't give you exact date. We test our mobile products extensively, and so it's often hard to be able to get exactly when the launch date going to be. Clearly, we have some Minions as the key products. We have a Star Wars product coming out. We have to some of our sports titles that you'll see and a lot of exciting expansions or additions to products like the Simpson or SimCity BuildIt, which have continued to build off of the strength of our platform there. In terms of the actual phasing, hard to say and I don't think it changes our overall phasing that we put in our new guidance. But we'll update you as that comes along.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. First off, a lot of anticipation around Star Wars, obviously, and it looks really great at E3. Just considering the release date is fairly fixed. I wonder how comfortable or confident you're around the studio's ability to lau
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First off, a lot of anticipation around Star Wars, obviously, and it looks really great at E3. Just considering the release date is fairly fixed. I wonder how comfortable or confident you're around the studio's ability to launch a fully finished product by the time November rolls around and then are you sticking with original $9 million to $10 million unit guidance for the game?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're feeling very good about the game right now. Again, as a reminder, this is a tried-and-true development team building on a frostbite engine. It's now launching number of products on this platform generation. And we're coming kind of the third phase o
componenttext: We're feeling very good about the game right now. Again, as a reminder, this is a tried-and-true development team building on a frostbite engine. It's now launching number of products on this platform generation. And we're coming kind of the third phase of development of this generation of products. So we feel like we have put all of the things in place that we need to deliver a great product. We had thousands of people play at E3. And one of the more robust setups we've had for in our E3 booth in recent years and we're looking at having literally tens or hundreds of thousands of people play on over 200 units at games week. So the code is all very playable. The quality is high. And the feedback so far from the player base has been very positive. On the 9 to 10, I'll let me take that.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just to clarify, no change obviously in shift date on that whatsoever. We're very confident that we should be able to get hit date based on what Andrew just told you. On the guidance, look. We're normally -- we normally do not raise guidance coming o
componenttext: Yes, just to clarify, no change obviously in shift date on that whatsoever. We're very confident that we should be able to get hit date based on what Andrew just told you. On the guidance, look. We're normally -- we normally do not raise guidance coming out of the first quarter. I think all of you know we have a fairly conservative mindset around guidance. This is the first time we've raised guidance in probably 10 or 15 years coming out of the first quarter because only 16% of our business is really booked in the first quarter. We're really excited about Battlefront. but we're also really excited about all of our products. And that excitement drove us to increase our guidance in the quarter. We haven't yet started to think about or talk about publicly what that means in terms of unit, partially because it's still early. We want to see how the reaction in games to all our price, including Battlefront, as well as how the fall plays out. So I would assume we'll have that discussion in October before we ship those products and more to come on that. But right now, think about the raise in guidance on revenues, strength across all of our products, including strength in the response around Battlefront.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: And just one quick one on the second quarter outlook versus a year ago. You mentioned the FX headwind in Sims 4, the comps there. But you also have the higher installed base in digital gross. And I think MEA is incremental. So it appeared the top line growth is still a possibility on the strength of the franchises. But are there any other moving parts I'm missing thing that might -- has impacted your initial outlook?

componenttext: Yes national, if look like the people industry had in terms of revenue. We're expecting strong review out of FIFA, Madden, NHL and NBA. But those are obviously they were there last year as well. I think the biggest and reveal only headwind comes out of FX and based on where we are today and FX rate today, we think that's relatively roughly $100 million relative to last year.

componenttext: So Peter, Andrew, are you able to share some of the underlying user data for FIFA Online 3 in China, active users, paying users, et cetera? So where are you in terms of deploying development talent to make that possible?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the first question FIFA Online 3. This is, of course, publishes our partners and Tencent there. So it's little early. As you recall, we waited soft launch. We're now in full commercial launch. We Can probably share a lot of data in the next earnings
componenttext: Well, the first question FIFA Online 3. This is, of course, publishes our partners and Tencent there. So it's little early. As you recall, we waited soft launch. We're now in full commercial launch. We Can probably share a lot of data in the next earnings call. As regard to your question with comparison to the West, obviously, there are very different experiences. This is a free to play game. It;s built on the Ultimate Team format, but is not a type game which is regular fee for game obviously is. From that perspective, I think the overriding similarity of soccer fans around the world, and Blake touched on this, we're riding high on soccer currently right now, coming of the women's World Cup and with a new domestic leagues, all about to start within the last 2 weeks. So obviously having that FIFA license for has been able to deploy across multiple geographies with multiple partners and in particular, in the biggest geographic in the world with a very strong partner in gives opportunity. We go forward the $31 million from the previous quarter into this quarter here. And as Blake as mentioned, on the previous call, we're looking at somewhere in the region about $10 million to $15 million per quarter as net revenue from our Tencent relationship.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of Star Wars, I don't think we've actually said that there's an annual Star Wars plan in place, but we do have a long-term contract with Disney. And we know Disney has plans for many Star Wars movies. And we're going to try to take advantage
componenttext: Yes, in terms of Star Wars, I don't think we've actually said that there's an annual Star Wars plan in place, but we do have a long-term contract with Disney. And we know Disney has plans for many Star Wars movies. And we're going to try to take advantage of the IP that are coming out of those movies. I do think what we have said is that our intention is to try over the next couple of years to have a first-person shooter as one of the core titles. This year obviously Star Wars Battlefront. Next year another Battlefield title. And as Andrew said, we're working on some other Star Wars title, Jay Ramin and are working on a core title right now. We don't have the timetable yet to announce that, but trust that you will see multiple Star Wars titles both on console and PC, as well as on mobile. We have at least one mobile title that's going to come out this year and we have more in the process as well. So lots to come on Star Wars and you'll hear more about that as we discuss our future guidance. We're very excited about the franchise and about our partnership.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: So on the pre-orders, we're seeing extremely strong pre-orders E3 as you can imagine. I would remind everybody on the call that more and more as we see digital start to ahold with our consumers less of a key indicator key lender indicator is how we predict our business here. But as he came out at E3, and more importantly, as Andrew mentioned, as we come out for what will be a pivotal moment for Starburst next week and Cologne, Germany when 265,000 consumers will descend on the Cologne Convention Center on Thursday on the loan will be trying desperately to get their hands on this title. We expect to see tremendous response from that. I've seen the build and the game looks very, very solid and we're excited to be able to share that. As regards the question regarding installed base, yes, $49 million at end of the calendar year. Just some data on that, we're now 20 months in and we go like-for-like on the previous generation, we're up 44% installed base hardware versus where we were with Xbox 360 PS3 and our tax rate for software is slightly ahead as well. When correcting for full game downloads -- digital full game dollars and hardware bundles, we're 6.1 right numbers versus 5.9 in the same period in the previous generation.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Brian, we haven't a fully they just said Sony announcement other than to say that it's hugely positive. Every time either Sony or Microsoft brings out information it's on the positive surprise outside. I think the NPD data showing the success of the M
componenttext: And Brian, we haven't a fully they just said Sony announcement other than to say that it's hugely positive. Every time either Sony or Microsoft brings out information it's on the positive surprise outside. I think the NPD data showing the success of the Microsoft 1 terabyte console as well as the continued strength in both Sony and Microsoft's product mix have been really strong. And a piece of that puzzle is if you're at E3, you saw the quality of software and not just ours, but the whole industry, and that bodes extremely well for generating interest in you're sitting on defense today getting out of buying a new console and we think that's going to do well in the next couple of years. So...

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: So you guys had a pretty sizable beat on gross margin in the first quarter, but it does not seem to be flowing to your fiscal year guidance. I wonder what the rationale behind that was? And then separately, as it relates to your sports titles, obviously, a lot of moving parts there. Any updated you in terms of in terms of directionally how businesses or how those franchises will perform in aggregate in your fiscal '16?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why don't -- let me take the gross margin question and then I'm going to let Andrew get the sports question. I think they're ready us a bit about math, right? We're able to raise our full year guidance on the bottom line and the top line, but with a sligh
componenttext: Why don't -- let me take the gross margin question and then I'm going to let Andrew get the sports question. I think they're ready us a bit about math, right? We're able to raise our full year guidance on the bottom line and the top line, but with a slight improvement in gross margin. But remember, third quarter gross margin gets somewhat impacted by the royalty bearing nature of our most Battlefront. So net net, we're seeing positive trend in gross margin, but with only 15% of the year gone, math just doesn't drive the gross margin numbers that much even though they got 10% or $0.10 increase in EPS. I think the good news there is a slight improvement in gross margin, nowhere near what we saw the first quarter, but just a slight improvement going forward. Those well for the earnings and the cash flow power and the business model. And that's why we're so focused on driving the digital side of our business because it's a huge value creator for us.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we think about our sports portfolio coming into Q2, again, as we have got more and more data on our player base, one of the greatest things that demonstrate the propensity to upgrade the next version is continually continued engagement in the current v
componenttext: As we think about our sports portfolio coming into Q2, again, as we have got more and more data on our player base, one of the greatest things that demonstrate the propensity to upgrade the next version is continually continued engagement in the current version. We're seeing very, very strong engagement across the portfolio right now, and that combined with a great feature set across our sports portfolio and the evolution and growing player base as a result of growing console cycle and increased forwardship of sports like stalker around the world, we are very encouraged and excited by what our sports portfolio can do through this quarter, but not just that as a result of the live services that we now build around our sports games, what it can do through this fiscal year and beyond.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And just got one. Blake, can you remind us what you're assuming in terms of FX detriment the top line in fiscal '16?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And just got one. Blake, can you remind us what you're assuming in terms of FX detriment the top line in fiscal '16?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a good question. As a reminder, we said at the start of last quarter and the pretty much hold that our revenue forecast on a like-for-like basis last year FX rate was $4.65 billion. We thought FX wud impact that by $250 million and that the t
componenttext: Yes. So it's a good question. As a reminder, we said at the start of last quarter and the pretty much hold that our revenue forecast on a like-for-like basis last year FX rate was $4.65 billion. We thought FX wud impact that by $250 million and that the to the $4.4 billion revenue guide. So obviously, under the new guidance, we're assuming $4.7 billion in revenue, the same FX impact, $250 million, that's the $4.45 billion in adjusted -- post-FX revenue. And we presented in our investor pack the FX rate. The reality is the euro is right about the same level as it was when we did our original guidance. We saw a little weakening in the dollar during quarter up to about 113 from 109, but that didn't last very long, back down around the 109 level. and the Great Britain pound, which is of is the big driver for things like FIFA, we saw -- the original guidance was $1.62. It's currently $1.56. So a little bit difference. But last year's full year average was $1.49. So we're still seeing some movement but pencils out to be roughly around that same $250 million headwind.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ben, it's Peter. Question as you saw announced a couple of days ago, yes, we've entered into a relationship with our partners with Nexon as well as of cource the first developers Respawn. Think of this as classic free-to-play game there, but do not t
componenttext: Hey, Ben, it's Peter. Question as you saw announced a couple of days ago, yes, we've entered into a relationship with our partners with Nexon as well as of cource the first developers Respawn. Think of this as classic free-to-play game there, but do not think of this as being particularly material to revenue. It's an interesting experiment in looking at that type of game and whether it plays in a free-to-play environment. We'll be interesting to see the results.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as relates to the -- as we've talked about, we're thinking about on a couple of different levels. We certainly believe that VR represents an opportunity for our industry as you think about our player's motivation to immerse themselves in cool, new wor
componenttext: And as relates to the -- as we've talked about, we're thinking about on a couple of different levels. We certainly believe that VR represents an opportunity for our industry as you think about our player's motivation to immerse themselves in cool, new worlds and explore new quarters. It's less that any 1 particular devise or piece of technology and more about how we abstract beyond that and ensure our core technology layer and digital platform and our core engine in Frostbite can facilitate experience as irrespective of which device consumer wants to use. Right now, we have a number of different incubation projects across the company, where we're looking at best-in-class new and innovative creative plays to experience our game in a virtuality environment. Still very early days, but we still were investing appropriately to prepare for time where that could provide a new and different and innovative for our players to experience our games.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Date just anything other than FIFA, what are your key drivers in China that we should be watching?
componenttext: Date just anything other than FIFA, what are your key drivers in China that we should be watching?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think FIFA is our biggest single driver. And I think they're the biggest driver is continued growth and popularity of soccer and that's a positive trend going on out is that rather world and particularly in places like China. You'll see additional new p
componenttext: I think FIFA is our biggest single driver. And I think they're the biggest driver is continued growth and popularity of soccer and that's a positive trend going on out is that rather world and particularly in places like China. You'll see additional new products come out that have similar approaches being partner and using known IP that resonates well in a Chinese markets. More to come there. But I think our real approach is to try to stay very focused and try to build great relationships with partners that will help drive the business. And that's worked for us really well in Korea with our Nexon partnership and we want to try to do the same thing with Tencent in China to really drive that business versus a lot of product in the market and hope something works. We're trying to be very, very focused.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Next one is coming from Mr. Mike Hickey from Benchmark Company.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015

componenttext: Nice to see the guidance going higher, too. It's awesome. I think on this. I'm going to hit it anyway. Just curious on your hiring of Jade. In the building of a new studio in Montral, as you said in your prepared remarks, it sounds like your first project is working with Amy yet and it also sounds like she's overseeing that studio. Wondering if this was an original development direction you are planning for you fairly need some additional expertise for this game's completion Star Wars that is rumored to be an open world experience. And I also wanted to confirm, you touched on it, but confirm that this new R&D expense related to motive was originally part $100 million or so that you announced previous quarter and I have a quick follow-up.

That's not a lot of people upfront. so it won't impact this year's guidance at all. And next year, we responsible that out. But you there was an next year guidance. I don't see it as a major driver of IP expense or EP or R&D expense over the near-term because we'll simply redial where our balance is around the world and where we're investing.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great question. I'll see if I can shed some light on how we think about this. There's really 2 call vectors as we think about this. The first is how do we build a live service that engages players being in, day out, week in, week out, month in, month out
componenttext: Great question. I'll see if I can shed some light on how we think about this. There's really 2 call vectors as we think about this. The first is how do we build a live service that engages players being in, day out, week in, week out, month in, month out broader and how do we build that into consistent and predictable engagement for our players of our business and what you're seeing with FIFA and the other properties including Battlefield and Madden and initial another is is that we are successfully navigating that shift and really leading from the front in an industry to drive great engagement opportunities for our players. The second vector as we think about that is then what's the appropriate business model for any given player to enjoy that experience? And I think it's insightful that you point out that it does subscription an opportunity. As it relates to subscription right now, we're very happy with the testing and experimentation analysis we've got going on with EA Access. And over time, we will evaluate based on this ongoing engagement and relationship and conversation with our players as to whether the extension of EA Access as a subscription or some of her this subscription will make player base but right now, our focus is on the continuing and driving about live service experience.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two things for you, guys. First, with the news of consoles expanding in China beyond the Shanghai free trade zone, what would it take for consoles, do you think, to actually gain traction in China changing from a massive PC environment to one that's more
componenttext: Two things for you, guys. First, with the news of consoles expanding in China beyond the Shanghai free trade zone, what would it take for consoles, do you think, to actually gain traction in China changing from a massive PC environment to one that's more acceptable consoles? Secondly, the big change of thought here. The convert that you have comes due in a year. I know you've got a hedge on that convert. But can you talk a little bit about -- can you use cash rather than delivering shares? How does the hedge impact that P&L when that convert eventually comes due?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the China piece and let Blake do with the convert. China, as you know, is a very interesting, diverse and dynamic marketplace, particularly for Western companies. In order for consoles to be supremely successful there, I think that we would have
componenttext: I'll take the China piece and let Blake do with the convert. China, as you know, is a very interesting, diverse and dynamic marketplace, particularly for Western companies. In order for consoles to be supremely successful there, I think that we would have to account for the culture sensibilities of the Chinese gameplaying population. We have to think about business model. We have to think about appropriate culturalized content and the ability to fulfill the motivations that they have for social connection and competition, which differs from how we play in the West or even in other Asian markets. I believe that both Sony and Microsoft are committed to driving the business there. I feel that we have content that should be able to kind of navigate through those key elements has appeal in China. But my sense is that it takes some time as has the overall market in China to really gain attraction and momentum that it has today.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: The convert, Eric -- so couple of things to note. So original value at the convert roughly $633 million. That has to be settled in cash. And then the upside component of that obviously selled in stock. Right now, the average stock price for the quarter, w
componenttext: The convert, Eric -- so couple of things to note. So original value at the convert roughly $633 million. That has to be settled in cash. And then the upside component of that obviously selled in stock. Right now, the average stock price for the quarter, which was $61.61, that would equal 6.6 million shares of stock that would be used to obviously sell the convert. We published it chart on our website, our IR website, that shows various stock levels I would that's all that and note that there's a difference between the GAAP share count and the non-GAAP share count because GAAP accounting excludes the benefit of the bond hedge so it shows the full dilution versus what comes in through the bond head where the non-GAAP share count is obviously unaffected by it. A couple of notes. As many people see with convert, particularly ones that are well in the money like ours, there often is early conversion request that come in. And shortly after the last coupon payment, we saw a jump in early conversion request. I believe people are simply making a calculation as do they take their money now or borrow money to carry it for the rest of the year. And typically the borrowing cost is offset, not fully offset by the coupon. And so you're seeing some early convergence. And we've had over $165 million of early convergence that will get paid out over the next 3 months. There's a time lapse. And so our assumption is we'll continue see some of that over the next year as people get closer to the conversion date next July. And our intention is to look through ways to obviously potentially refinance that in a capital structure. We talk about a potential permanent layer of debt or another convert and/or just paying it all out, and we're looking through all those options and more to come. But we appreciate the fact that there will be a lot of dilution and we're looking at ways to minimize that dilution going forward.

componenttext: Doug, it's Peter. So yes, just let me say again. So when we look at this cycle, let's call that's current Genx Xbox One, PS4, et. al. versus last gen, we're at we will be we believe the installed base of hardware the under 2015 will be $49 million. componenttext: And I guess -- let me add to that. We saw at the tail end of the gen -- the 360 and the PlayStation 3 cycle, full game downloads around 5% level. All of those trends continue to see positive movements, and we've heard several things from our other members in our industry. And so we're very, very excited about the potential for continuing to drive that part of the business.
