headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kay. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SE
componenttext:
Thank you, Kay. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call. Please note that our SEC filings on our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared remarks. Lastly, after the call, we will post our prepared remarks and audio replay of this call and the transcript. 
A quick calendar note, our Q3 earnings call is scheduled for Thursday, January 28, 2016.
This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events and results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. Electronic Arts makes these statements as of today, October 29, 2015, and disclaims any duty to update them. During this call, unless otherwise stated, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not the intended to be considered in isolation from as a substitute for, or superior to our gap results. We encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated. Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Q2 FY '16 was a strong quarter for Electronic Arts as we delivered new EA SPORTS experiences and dynamic live services for our players. Revenue margin and earnings were above our guidance, and we are raising our full year outlook to reflect
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Q2 FY '16 was a strong quarter for Electronic Arts as we delivered new EA SPORTS experiences and dynamic live services for our players. Revenue margin and earnings were above our guidance, and we are raising our full year outlook to reflect continuing strength in our business and excitement for our upcoming titles, including Star Wars Battlefront. 
To understand how Electronic Arts is delivering for our players today, we look at player engagement in our games and services. We see our opportunity along 3 key vectors: bringing in more players to experience our games and services, enabling them to spend more time with our games -- with the games they love and making it possible to connect through more platforms and delivery models. 
Time is the most valuable commodity we have in today's digital world with every new game, every update in our live services and every community interaction, we are focused on delivering more value for our players through deep and personal engagement. Highlights from our second quarter demonstrate how more players are spending more time on more platforms in our games today. 
Monthly average players increased 30% year-over-year across our ad and will EA SPORTS franchises that launched new titles in Q2: Madden NFL 16, NHL 16 and FIFA 16. Our live services for Battlefield Hardline and Battlefield 4 are thriving many months after launch, with more than 6 million monthly average players across the 2 experiences. 
Madden NFL model launched a full game update this year instead of a new app download. The result was a seamless experience for players which increased retention and resulted in game sessions up more than 300% over last year. 
And last but not least, EA Access is accelerating. The subscriber base more than doubled in the last 2 quarters. We've added 5 new games to the vault this year and we're excited about what we're learning as players engage through service. 
These titles and live services as well as many more in our portfolio are giving us strong momentum moving into the holiday season. Looking ahead, I'll be joined in Q3 by 2 of our most exciting and groundbreaking new experiences. First, the return of Need for Speed this year, with players able to join a trial via EA Access today and launching for everyone on Xbox One and PlayStation 4 beginning November 3. Excitement in the community has been growing as fans learn more about the cards, customization and unique storage in the game. The game looks fantastic and after close beta connected earlier in October, the Ghost Games team have been working directly with community feedback to deliver the experience our players want. With more than 70 different customization categories and twice the amount of road to rate as our previous games, the passion for speed and power culture will be at unleashed in the new Need for Speed. 
Starting in 19 days, that galaxy far far away will once again beat the center of our universe as Star Wars Battlefront launches around the world. Engagement in and around the record-breaking beta was huge, with more than 9.5 million players logging on to play, 19 million viewers tuning into video streams and almost 3 mentioned per second in social not works during the beta week. 
Stability and scalability of our online services continues to be a core focus for us. In addition to our extensive internal testing, the members of gameplay hours logged during the beta across multiplayer, single player and top modes further tested our infrastructure to help prepare a stable experience for our players at launch and beyond. 
Over the next few weeks, innovative new experiences will allow players to connect and learn more about Star Wars Battlefront. Our most average Star Wars Battlefront fans can sign up for free to receive exclusive content and advanced access to new information as that began. Through our largest ever user-generated content program we've ever launched, awesome and inspiring moment from the game will be shared with millions in the player community, and a fully emerge web experience will put fans right in the world of Star Wars Battlefront. Through door, our integration with our upcoming film will ensure was fully connected to the rising passion for Star Wars that is captivating the world. Come join us in Star Wars Battlefront beginning November 17 or November 12 for EA Access members. 
As we continue our focus on putting player first on Electronic Arts, was strike the quality and innovation in every experience. In addition to stability, security and availability, we are taking creative leaps to make each game memorable and fun. We'll always work to take the necessary time to get the combination right for our players. And early this afternoon, we announced that we are shifting Mirror's Edge Catalyst released to May 24, 2016. We're going to take a few additional months to make the City of Glass and the unique first-person action in Mirror's Edge Catalyst even more spectacular. With players spending more time in our games and live services and to starting new experience we're launching this quarter, we're looking forward to the holiday season and the remainder of the fiscal year for Electronic Arts. Now I'll hand the call over to Blake for a deeper look at our financials.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.15 billion, which was $71 million or 7% above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 6% lower than the prior year's as a result of an FX headwind of $110 million and The Sims 4 launch last year. However, o
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.15 billion, which was $71 million or 7% above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 6% lower than the prior year's as a result of an FX headwind of $110 million and The Sims 4 launch last year. However, on a constant currency basis, revenue would've been 3% greater than last year's, thanks to strong launches of our EA SPORTS titles led by FIFA 16 and Madden NFL 16 and associated Ultimate Team live services. As well as frontline success, we saw ongoing strength from our catalog, particularly The Sims 4 and Battlefield. 
In addition to our strong performance, this quarter's revenue includes a $30 million benefit from the recognition of some revenue from special editions of sports games sold in the quarter. It relates the Ultimate Team content included in these versions, we had originally forecast to recognize in Q3. 
Our non-GAAP digital net revenue for the quarter increased 6% year-over-year to $408 million, 42% of this quarter's revenue. The trailing 12-month digital net revenue was up 15% to a record $2.31 billion. Breaking down our digital revenue into its key components highlights the performance of each of these businesses this quarter. 
Extra content and freemium contributed $195 million, up 27% over the prior year. The principal driver of that growth was Ultimate Team across our sports franchises. In addition to the strength of t e live services, we benefited from an extra week of FIFA 16 sales in the quarter compared to last year. The new games modes we added to Madden NFL 16 and FIFA 16 are proving effective in deepening engagement. In addition, FIFA Online 3, our PC free-to-play title for China and Korea continues to perform well and its tracking to our expectation. 
Mobile generated $113 million in the quarter. The free download component was up 2% or 9% up [ph] the constant currency. During the quarter, we launched Need for Speed No Limits, EA SPORTS FIFA 16 Ultimate Team and a full game update of Madden NFL Mobile. Madden has been the top grossing -- top 5 grossing given the U.S. on the iPhone Apple App Store in October. 
These new titles, together with the just launched Minions Paradise, the upcoming Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes and our existing live services will help continue to grow our mobile business. 
Full game PC and console downloads generated $89 million of revenue, down 5% over the prior year, due in part to FX. As constant currency, this revenue would've increased as the growth in console downloads more than offset the absence of The Sims 4 this year. 
Our new titles in the quarter averaged around 20% for game downloads, with the exception of FIFA which skewed lower due to strong retail sales in Europe. 
Subscriptions, advertising and other digital revenue contributed $83 million, down 9% from last year due to the natural decline in Battlefield 4 Premium revenues. EA Access is delivering strong sustained growth. And finally, with regard to subscriptions, we launched a major expansion for Star Wars: The Old Republic in Tuesday. Subscriptions are up 31% since the expansion was announced to their highest level since February 2014. We're optimistic about this continued performance in terms of both subscribers and free-to-play in relates to the first Star Wars movie in a decade. 
Moving on to gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 65.4%, a decrease from last year's 66.1% but above our guidance of 63%. Last year's Q2 gross margin was exceptionally strong due to The Sims 4. About 100 basis points of the margin outperformance this quarter was driven by the $30 million in high margin revenue mentioned earlier. A stronger-than-expected product and service mix also drive margins above our guidance. 
Our non-GAAP operating expenses for the quarter were $479 million, down $18 million year-on-year, driven by FX. The improvement on guidance was driven by phasing and continued cost control. At constant currency, OpEx would've been up approximately $16 million, chiefly driven by increased investment in R&D. 
The result in non-GAAP diluted EPS was $0.65 per share, which is $0.25 better than guidance due to our strong top line performance, continued cost management and the revenue-facing earlier. At constant currency, EPS would've grown year -- over last year. 
Our cash and short-term investment at the end of the quarter were $2.59 billion or approximately $8.32 per share. 57% of this cash and short-term investment balances held onshore. This is down from 64% held onshore last quarter, the difference being driven by the redemptions of our convertible notes and stock repurchases. 
During Q2, we settled close to $200 million in early conversions of our convertible notes. And as of yesterday, we received notices for an additional $95 million to settle in Q3. We have updated the dilution table on our website accordingly. We also repurchased 1.8 million shares on a cost of $126 million, leaving $798 million in our 2-year, $1 billion buyback program we began in May 2015. The current rate of repurchase just keeps us on track to complete the full $1 billion in that time. 
Net cash provided by operating activities for the quarter was $9 million. Operating cash flow was down $174 million from last year as a result of fewer launches in Q1 of this year compared to last and also to the timing -- due to the timing of various items. On a trailing 12-month basis, operating cash flow was $818 million. 
Turning to guidance. Due to our continued strong performance, we are again increasing our full year outlook. The open beta for Star Wars Battlefront was exceptionally well received by players. Consequently, we're rising -- raising our unit forecast for sell-in during fiscal year 2016 to approximately 13 million units. This is partially offset by increased FX headwinds and our decision to move Mirror's Edge Catalyst into fiscal 2017. And remember that the $30 million in this quarter was already in our annual outlook as part of our anticipated Q3 revenue. 
Our new full year guidance for non-GAAP revenue is $4.5 billion, up $50 million on our prior outlook. Our guidance for non-GAAP EPS increased by $0.15 to $3 per share. We anticipate an operating margin of approximately 28%. Since the start of this fiscal year, we've raised our guidance by $100 million in revenue and by $0.25 on earnings. 
The GAAP guidance becomes $4.4 billion in revenue and $2.32 of fully diluted EPS. Regarding cash flow for the full fiscal year, we are increasing our operating cash flow guidance to approximately $1.2 billion. Our capital expense forecast remains approximately $100 million, resulting in a free cash flow forecast of approximately $1.1 billion. 
Guidance for our third quarter is for non-GAAP net revenue to be $1.78 billion, 24% higher than last year's. Growth is driven by the launches of Star Wars Battlefront and Need for Speed plus the growth of live services, particularly Ultimate game. FX presents a year-on-year headwind of around $110 million to Q3 revenues. 
Non-GAAP gross margin is forecasted to be 71.5%. We expect our Q3 non-GAAP operating expenses to be $540 million, up slightly year-on-year, driven by increased investment in R&D and facing from Q2, offset by FX. This results in a non-GAAP diluted EPS of $1.75 per share as compared to $1.22 last year. Our Q3 GAAP net revenue is expected to be $1.08 billion as compared to $1.13 billion in the prior year. GAAP earnings per share is expected to be a loss of $0.17 as compared to earnings of $0.44 last year. 
Our business exceeded our expectations again this quarter. FIFA 16 in particular have a very successful launch as measured by number of units sales and by engagement level. This has provided a solid foundation upon which to grow our live services through the product cycle. Reception of the Star Wars Battlefront beta has led us to increase our unit forecast and early indications for Need for Speed are excellent. The growth of our console-installed base and powerful mobile devices continue to fuel the growth of our business. We're looking forward to an excellent holiday season and another year of strong earnings and cash flow growth. Now I'll turn the call back to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. Around the world, billions of hours a week are spent playing video games. No matter what device you're playing on, what type of experience you seek or where you are in the world, games are becoming a more meaningful part of our lives. The o
componenttext: Thanks, Blake. Around the world, billions of hours a week are spent playing video games. No matter what device you're playing on, what type of experience you seek or where you are in the world, games are becoming a more meaningful part of our lives. The opportunity connects more people to amazing experiences and each other through play have never been more profound. Electronic Arts, we're focused on delivering more stunning games and groundbreaking services that will inspire the world of play together. Every fantasy like Star Wars Battlefront that's been generation to fans, EA SPORTS experiences that unite millions of passionate players, mobile titles like Need for Speed No Limit Sims City Builder and Madden NFL mobile that can emerge you no matter where you are or how much time you have, and services like EA Access and Origin that are helping players through our more games and shared to play experience with friends. It's been a strong first half of FY '16 for Electronic Arts, and we have amazing opportunities still ahead of us. The games and services we are delivering represent EA's greatest strength: pioneering, creativity and passion, channeled into experiences that will inspire play for a long time to come. We're excited for the road ahead. Now Blake, Peter and I are here for your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kay, could you ready for questions now. Thank you.
componenttext: Kay, could you ready for questions now. Thank you.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Chris Merwin from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Chris Merwin from Barclays.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You obviously continue to make a lot of progress on the margin front and you're at slightly more than 50% digital as of last fiscal year. So as that shift continues, can you just update us on what the long-term margin target for the business looks like ju
componenttext: You obviously continue to make a lot of progress on the margin front and you're at slightly more than 50% digital as of last fiscal year. So as that shift continues, can you just update us on what the long-term margin target for the business looks like just in terms of a non-GAAP operating income? And then secondly, extra content sales growth reaccelerated really nicely in 2Q and I think you mentioned that you launch of FIFA 16 and FIFA Online 3 were drivers there. So should we expect the momentum to continue there through year-end and what you implicitly including in your guidance just in terms of extra content for the full year?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's Blake. In terms of the longer-term target, we haven't really given detailed long-term targets. What we have told people is that if the continued on the same page of digital growth as we've seen over the last couple of years, we should be able
componenttext: Yes. So it's Blake. In terms of the longer-term target, we haven't really given detailed long-term targets. What we have told people is that if the continued on the same page of digital growth as we've seen over the last couple of years, we should be able to generate at least 100 basis points of gross margin expansion each year. Historically, it succeeded that level. But I think at a minimum, we should be able to see that. If you combine that with control around our operating expenses and continued movement towards more digital marketing, we should be able to see earnings growth and our target is to try to get to earnings growth at least above 10% or greater closer to 50% on a year-to-date basis if we can. That's obviously general targets, we'll give you the detail guidance for our FY '17 at the end of the year. And to the extent we have an update on that, we'll let you know, but we're continuing to be excited obviously on where the business and the potential is. In terms of FIFA, the guidance for extra content and ultimately, the guidance for extra content that we originally gave for the full year was around 10% growth of extra content. We've been exceeding that and we hope that we would continue to hit that target or beat target over time. We're very excited about the continued engagement levels that people are showing in all of our sports titles around extra content as well as the potential for extra content in other places in our portfolio. As far as FIFA Online 3 goes, in China, we had originally given of guidance that, that should be around $10 million to $15 million a quarter and we're seeing that levels, and we're pretty comfortable that, that continues to grow over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Stephen Ju from Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Stephen Ju from Crdit Suisse.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Blake, I mean, you just raised your Star Wars unit guidance. I think you give the overall revenue-facing guidance on the slide deck. But what's embedded in your guidance for how Star Wars will be facing between your third and fourth quarters? And also sec
componenttext: Blake, I mean, you just raised your Star Wars unit guidance. I think you give the overall revenue-facing guidance on the slide deck. But what's embedded in your guidance for how Star Wars will be facing between your third and fourth quarters? And also secondarily, I think you mentioned 20% sort of digital download. how far behind is the European consumer in terms of full game download adoption on the console? And are you seeing that uptick curve, I guess, follow on a similar path as what you've already seen in the U.S.?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Stephen. Good questions. I don't have the number off the top of my head. But you should assume that a fairly large portion of the original sell-in comes to the third quarter and then depending on how that does through this Christmas season, w
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Stephen. Good questions. I don't have the number off the top of my head. But you should assume that a fairly large portion of the original sell-in comes to the third quarter and then depending on how that does through this Christmas season, we'll see the rest in the fourth quarter. So roughly, probably 75-25. In terms of full game download. A couple of things to remember, we still sell Gen3 products and Gen3 products are typically doing full game downloads at a much lower level. And then second, our business, particularly FIFA is skewed heavily towards Europe and 2 factors bring down full game downloads today in Europe. One is bandwidth speed in some countries; and two, is many retailers in Europe particularly in Great Britain used FIFA as a way of driving traffic into the store and they like a physical copy to do that. We're seeing very strong full game downloads continue in North America. And as a reminder, the PC business that we have, we see full game downloads, they're roughly 75%. And so there's still a lot of headroom we believe in the full game downloads opportunity for us going forward.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next 1 is coming from Colin Sebastian from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Next 1 is coming from Colin Sebastian from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: It's actually Ben on for Colin. I have 2 questions more strategically. Could you talk a little bit about your EA SPORTS initiatives, and I going forward you might have the right from sports leagues to pursue some more formal tournament play? And then secondly, are there any plans for annual sequels or franchise extension for Star Wars or the kids look more like Battlefield or Titanfall?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ben, I'll take the first question, it's Peter, regarding EA SPORTS but I want to remind everybody on the call that EA has been doing EA SPORTS but it's been a fundamental part of the way we've engagement our consumers for over a decade beginning with the
componenttext: Ben, I'll take the first question, it's Peter, regarding EA SPORTS but I want to remind everybody on the call that EA has been doing EA SPORTS but it's been a fundamental part of the way we've engagement our consumers for over a decade beginning with the FIFA interactive World Cup. We partnered with -- in particular, with FIFA with all of the individual leagues around the world, with tournaments and have been doing that for a number of years now. So from the perspective of our EA SPORTS strategy, it's well on that executional level. And we think about partnering with the sports leagues themselves, we have those conversations and whilst we got nothing to announce it, stay tuned because I think there's a lot of energy around this right now. We're obviously a very important part of that. Our IP has been used by many of the EA SPORTS leagues to be able to drive their business. And we fully intend to be part of this going forward here. No real announcements yet at a higher level, but please rest assured that it's very high on our radar.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Andrew. To the second question around Star Wars and analyzation. Again, with they have talked about is we have a long-term partnership around the Star Wars license, and we expect that we will launch many titles as part of that long-term relationship.
componenttext: It's Andrew. To the second question around Star Wars and analyzation. Again, with they have talked about is we have a long-term partnership around the Star Wars license, and we expect that we will launch many titles as part of that long-term relationship. In terms of annualizing that in any particular way, we've made no announcements on that. And certainly, what we're always looking at this we think across our portfolio is where there was an added opportunity for engagement. What we talked about in the prepared remarks is we still have 6 million people engaging regularly in both Battlefield 4 and Battlefield Hardline. And it's important we think about our business not just as a launch business but as a live service and relationship business that we factor in when it's appropriate to launch new things. So a lot of come that in the future, but certainly expect more Star Wars titles from us. But no decision made as to specific timing as yet.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the gross margin structure, I think we've told people that the license with Disney is a fairly typical royalty license and most of our royalty license, they're in high single digit to low double digits. And assume that Disney license is there.
componenttext: Okay. So on the gross margin structure, I think we've told people that the license with Disney is a fairly typical royalty license and most of our royalty license, they're in high single digit to low double digits. And assume that Disney license is there. What we try to do is offset some of that cost by lowering our marketing expense and clearly leveraging the strength of all the activities out there around Star Wars is allowing us to do that. And you'll see a lot of joint marketing between us and Disney as well as us and Sony to try to leverage our partners to be able to offset some that. It will impact gross margins slightly as you've seen in our guidance for the quarter, but we don't see it as a big issue for an overall profitability to the company. On the full game download sites, the one caveat, I would add there is my many, it shouldn't be that would really defer dramatically from any other title with the one exception is it could be a title as a heavy-gifting title in the quarter just because Star Wars is a top list of many kids and teens out there what they want for Christmas. And so in gifting titles tend to be more physical versus a code, and so you might tend to see that. That could be the counterbalanced by the fact that we'll see in another 10 million to 15 million you consoles sold in the next 2 months in the Christmas time. And many of this people made use to download digitally, particularly it's a larger storage consoles. What was your second part of your question?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That was great feedback. The second one is on FIFA and really does force catalog is encouraging to see the 30% player growth. Is there any reason to expect Ultimate Team to not also be up 30%. Is there anything you can call out either this ye
componenttext: Okay, great. That was great feedback. The second one is on FIFA and really does force catalog is encouraging to see the 30% player growth. Is there any reason to expect Ultimate Team to not also be up 30%. Is there anything you can call out either this year or last year that would make it be up or down?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were cautious the tail end of last year because we've had some issues with Brean farmers. We've adjusted the new FIFA Ultimate Team to try to prevent those issues as a constant battle. That would be our only cautioned going forward. So far we haven't s
componenttext: We were cautious the tail end of last year because we've had some issues with Brean farmers. We've adjusted the new FIFA Ultimate Team to try to prevent those issues as a constant battle. That would be our only cautioned going forward. So far we haven't seen any impact from that. What we are seeing this increased interest in Ultimate Team. We put in both in FIFA and Madden this year at draft mode which was essentially a way to help people understand how Ultimate Team works and how drafting and building at Teamworks. And we're finding that, that increases the engagement, increases the interest in entering into Ultimate Team. And so our hope is to continue to try to build that business across all of our sports franchises. And so far, things are going very well.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Next 1 is from Brian Pitz with Jefferies.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Of the 9.5 million beta players on Star Wars, what is the overlap audience with the 6 million still playing Battlefield 4 in Hardline. Is Star Wars essentially bringing you gamers into the Battlefield-type of game? And also any updates on preorders, inclu
componenttext: Of the 9.5 million beta players on Star Wars, what is the overlap audience with the 6 million still playing Battlefield 4 in Hardline. Is Star Wars essentially bringing you gamers into the Battlefield-type of game? And also any updates on preorders, including the $50 deal season pass? I love to hear that how the deal see attach rate compared to prior Battlefield releases.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part on the 9.5 million. I don't have the data on hand. Anecdotally, what we have seen is that Star Wars is bringing in 2 groups that are very important groups to us. One are gamers that have lapsed. Traditionally, who have been big ga
componenttext: I'll take the first part on the 9.5 million. I don't have the data on hand. Anecdotally, what we have seen is that Star Wars is bringing in 2 groups that are very important groups to us. One are gamers that have lapsed. Traditionally, who have been big gamers in the past and maybe haven't played for a while and it's certainly been a catalyst for those people to come back into the gaming universe or the console. And two, onboarding a new younger age demographic. So as we think about 9.5 million while it's absolutely across over around our portion [ph] of the category that we have very good and strong relationships with, we're very energized by the opportunity that bringing one, lapse gaming group as well as adding new younger demographic going forward. And remember that this is a title as a shooter title that will be more appropriate for younger players and maybe some other shooter titles in the market.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Preorders. I think when you look back and you they can add or how powerful this beta was for us and that's certainly for tremendous peer order growth. Every week, subsequent to the beta, we had 9.5 million users who have been [ph] in 1.6 million minutes o
componenttext: Preorders. I think when you look back and you they can add or how powerful this beta was for us and that's certainly for tremendous peer order growth. Every week, subsequent to the beta, we had 9.5 million users who have been [ph] in 1.6 million minutes of gameplay. On top of that, we were very fortunate obviously that Force Awakens movie trailer came went on top of that, and that's allowed us to be able to generate even more publicity for the game as people start to anticipate the movie in mid-December. You combine that with all the engagement that our players are creating content itself, a lot of user generated concert with millions of hours gameplay coming out on the beta on Twitch. Now Han Solo was here. We say great, but don't get cocky kid. Our ability to be able to deliver games list is solid. And the preorders are excellent so you've heard from growth Blake and Andrew, we feel very good about 13 million units.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Battlefield from season past. As we've seen with Battlefield with Battlefield Premium, our ability to extend and as you've seen with 16 million people Battlefield 4 and Battlefield Premium is key, the engagement numbers and we see a season past as integra
componenttext: Battlefield from season past. As we've seen with Battlefield with Battlefield Premium, our ability to extend and as you've seen with 16 million people Battlefield 4 and Battlefield Premium is key, the engagement numbers and we see a season past as integral to that. What we've announced is 4 extra packs over the next 12 to 18 months coming post launch profit, and our ability to do that to be very clear about FY '17, a revenue for most of it, you'll see both new universes, you're going to see new player actions, obviously new weaponry as well. We think this added engagement and we think the ability for us to be able to deliver against what we need to be able to do from a season past increases the engagement and a very important part of keeping the content fresh and our players engaged.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next 1 comes from Arvind Bhatia from Stern Agee.
componenttext: Next 1 comes from Arvind Bhatia from Stern Agee.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a couple of questions. One is Blake, if you can maybe talk a little bit more about the $30 million revenue Battlefield, maybe some clarification there. I think I heard you say it was already part of the guidance. And then Andrew, just your
componenttext: I wanted to ask a couple of questions. One is Blake, if you can maybe talk a little bit more about the $30 million revenue Battlefield, maybe some clarification there. I think I heard you say it was already part of the guidance. And then Andrew, just your thoughts on virtual reality. Any update there now that we have a little bit more clarity in the marketplace? And then one last one, can you maybe talk about Need for Speed, how the beta, what are the size of the beta and kind of the unit expectations this is the last one?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll answer first the $30 million. When we planned our guidance essentially, we sell special editions of some of the sports games, FIFA and Madden, for example. And part of those special editions include Ultimate Team currency, and we decide how to def
componenttext: So I'll answer first the $30 million. When we planned our guidance essentially, we sell special editions of some of the sports games, FIFA and Madden, for example. And part of those special editions include Ultimate Team currency, and we decide how to defer that over time in conjunction with our internal accounting team and our external auditors. As we got into the quarter, we determined that some of the content we thought we would defer, we actually didn't defer. We are able to book it in this quarter. And we wanted to be transparent on that. So people want to understood what are the source of our overall delivery. And two, understood that, that was just shifting between 2 quarters.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, on VR, our position hasn't changed at this juncture. Again, as he said in the past, and I personally very bullish on VR and believe that it will be an integral part of our industry and our vision on a go-forward basis. As we think about what playe
componenttext: Thanks, on VR, our position hasn't changed at this juncture. Again, as he said in the past, and I personally very bullish on VR and believe that it will be an integral part of our industry and our vision on a go-forward basis. As we think about what players are trying to do is immersed themselves inside these wonderful world and experiences that we create and that it overcomes the social disconnect created by sitting 10 feet or 3 feet or 1 feet -- 1 foot from a screen. With that, we don't expect it will have a material revenue impact in the near future. We still think there is work to be done to get to a point where this is really a mass-market consumer proposition that delivers great via immersive experiences from a mass community. But at the same time, we are investing heavily in ensuring our Frostbite engine has all of the capability to deliver spectacular VR experiences. So we are well positioned as this market develops.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this is Peter, the Need for Speed beta, very successful for us. As I think most of you on the call know Need for Speed now is available to player if you're EA Access member as of today. The team has always with the beta results to weak and do some las
componenttext: And this is Peter, the Need for Speed beta, very successful for us. As I think most of you on the call know Need for Speed now is available to player if you're EA Access member as of today. The team has always with the beta results to weak and do some last minute polishing to the game. Every indication in preorders are very strong around the world. Every indication this will be another successful launch having been 2 years away from consumers as we see the numbers coming in, in the final few days here for next week. So Need for Speed goes live next Tuesday in the United States and Canada and at the end of the week and rest of the world.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next 1 is coming from Drew Crum of Stifel.
componenttext: Next 1 is coming from Drew Crum of Stifel.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you remind us what the incremental FX hit is for fiscal '16 now and what the revenue foregone is from the shifts of Mirror's Edge?
componenttext: Can you remind us what the incremental FX hit is for fiscal '16 now and what the revenue foregone is from the shifts of Mirror's Edge?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So roughly Mirror's Edge, you should think about it as $70-ish million title for that quarter, so moving out of the fourth quarter. And our original FX guidance was that roughly $250 million or $290 million -- originally, it was $250 million. And we think
componenttext: So roughly Mirror's Edge, you should think about it as $70-ish million title for that quarter, so moving out of the fourth quarter. And our original FX guidance was that roughly $250 million or $290 million -- originally, it was $250 million. And we think it's probably closer to $300 million now.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then any launch metrics aside from the mobile performance you can offer and any commentary around the full game download performance of that franchise?
componenttext: Okay, good. And then any launch metrics aside from the mobile performance you can offer and any commentary around the full game download performance of that franchise?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the Madden franchise you mean?
componenttext: In terms of the Madden franchise you mean?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Madden NFL 16?
componenttext: Yes, Madden NFL 16?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's been pretty consistent. Obviously, it's a dominant North American title relative to FIFA, and so we tend to see higher full game downloads on Madden than we have with FIFA globally for the stuff that mentioned earlier. And so you're seeing north of 2
componenttext: It's been pretty consistent. Obviously, it's a dominant North American title relative to FIFA, and so we tend to see higher full game downloads on Madden than we have with FIFA globally for the stuff that mentioned earlier. And so you're seeing north of 20% on Madden obviously. And as the season goes on, we find that the initial purchasers tend to be -- the people who line up at the retail stores at midnight with their football jerseys on, obviously, that skews the early days of Madden. But by midseason, we tend to see levels creeping up closer to 40% at least on based on last year's data. We're not yet sure but strong focus on that. And the strength of Ultimate Team with Madden has been very powerful last year. I think that draws more and more people into the digital purchases as part of that ongoing gameplay.

componenttext: I wish I could translated, but we don't think about it that way because we think about it around engagement. Clearly, it will show unit growth but the 30% really, is a measure of not just people buying the initial game but playing the game. It's hard to put -- those are apples and oranges in that respect, but you should take that as continued unit growth in FIFA which we are seeing.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you know, given the strength this year, they're already concerns about comping revenue growth next year. I don't want to get too far ahead of ourselves in the guidance, but how should we think about the types of the games and the game ar
componenttext: Okay. And then as you know, given the strength this year, they're already concerns about comping revenue growth next year. I don't want to get too far ahead of ourselves in the guidance, but how should we think about the types of the games and the game are going to come next year that will help comp again Star Wars? And then following up on Arvin's view, our question, we have to keep asking these. But is EA going to wait until there's mass-market installed base or could we see at least limited view our experiences during the launch window for some of the '16 VR hardware launches?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Andrew touch on the VR if he like, but I'll touch on the other question. I think we try to resist giving full year guidance ahead of time. We have mentioned in the past, on our past calls that you should expect another Battlefield title coming ne
componenttext: I'll let Andrew touch on the VR if he like, but I'll touch on the other question. I think we try to resist giving full year guidance ahead of time. We have mentioned in the past, on our past calls that you should expect another Battlefield title coming next year. We've shown Mass Effect at E3 this year. You should expect that again. And there's some indication of this some other titles obviously that are popular along those lines like Titanfall or others. But we are very confident we can continue to grow the business, and we also are confident that the Star Wars franchise will live well beyond this year. And we think like Battlefield, it will be a  long tail on Star Wars into -- or helping drive our FY '17 business.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: On VR, what we talked about in our prepared remarks is our great strengths, productivity, passion. One of these things is pioneering. And our desire as a company to lead our belief that we have a responsibility given our position in the industry to lead.
componenttext: On VR, what we talked about in our prepared remarks is our great strengths, productivity, passion. One of these things is pioneering. And our desire as a company to lead our belief that we have a responsibility given our position in the industry to lead. Part of why we are investing at an engine level is so that we can drive from a leadership position. While we don't have anything to I announced today certainly for next year, we are looking at opportunities to do things sooner and earlier than complete mass-market adoption. But again, we will be getting to a point. It's less about is there must market adoption and more about is the technology ready for mass-market adoption. And that's what we're looking to right now. But we absolutely have a desire to lead as is our responsibility for the position we have in the industry.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we can't comment of the because we just don't know. We can't do probably no more than we do. So just reserves any comments. And in terms of our of our acquisition strategy, nothings really changed. We look at a lot of opportunities but we're very exc
componenttext: Yes, we can't comment of the because we just don't know. We can't do probably no more than we do. So just reserves any comments. And in terms of our of our acquisition strategy, nothings really changed. We look at a lot of opportunities but we're very excited about the opportunities we have internally. Both our own IP, we've got quite a few things coking as you've seen. We've hired Jade Raymond from to help us build some new products. Amy Hennig as well. So there's a huge opportunity for us to continue to build our own IP as well as leverage our great partnerships for people like Disney and Lucas to build off of Star Wars or any of our any licensed IP. So we see very little need right now but we keep our eyes open. We're always interested in seeing how things are evolving out there.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Cool, fair enough. And I guess thinking about those platform. The depths have apparently shifted. It looks like it's working towards the calendar year '16 launch. Just sort of wondering how you plan to plan your resources to that emerging platform? Do you anticipate being more aggressive on the front end or perhaps more a little bit cautious given the that performed expectations?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would address that slightly differently. As we look to the future, we see a world where more people applying on more platforms and more geographies than ever before. We see the platforms cycle now not just as a traditional 6-year console cycle but it's
componenttext: I would address that slightly differently. As we look to the future, we see a world where more people applying on more platforms and more geographies than ever before. We see the platforms cycle now not just as a traditional 6-year console cycle but it's kind it's a 6-month refresh rates on mobile devices, Smart TV, Internet and refrigerators or whatever it might be. And what we're doing in terms of resource allocation is really investing at a core digital platform level, at an engine level and at a game architecture level to ensure that we are able to deliver amazing experiences, fixed interest -- fixed interest and beyond, 2-minute to 2-hour session times and beyond across any and all relevant devices where gamers are playing. And as it relates to Nintendo, we've got a tremendous relationship with them over the years, and we will evaluate any and all opportunities with them in the same way we do all platform opportunities.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that question. As it relates to any and all of our products, what our players are telling us, particularly if they're engaged online with their friends is that they want to play our games longer and more frequently and for more
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that question. As it relates to any and all of our products, what our players are telling us, particularly if they're engaged online with their friends is that they want to play our games longer and more frequently and for more hours at a time than ever before. And our objective any time we provide additional content in any form where the free or pay is to ensure that in all cases we provide value for the investment of any money and the investment of their time and in all things, we are expanding and enhancing the experience so they can continue to enjoy playing the games we make with their friends for many months and years to come.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on marketing expense. It's hard to look at any 1 quarter and see a major trend because of how titles fall, and we may have marketing expenses in 2 quarters ahead of the title or getting spread over multiple quarters. And so our -- but our generally vi
componenttext: And on marketing expense. It's hard to look at any 1 quarter and see a major trend because of how titles fall, and we may have marketing expenses in 2 quarters ahead of the title or getting spread over multiple quarters. And so our -- but our generally view is we've been working very closely with all of the people involved in marketing to really leverage the engagement we have with our consumer base. We're connected to all of our consumers. We have a unique opportunity to better target our marketing activity to those consumers and not needing to use some of the less -- the more traditional marketing vehicles that have less effectiveness. And you're going to see a lot more of us in the future. You'll hear more -- you'll see things related to Star Wars, for example, over the next couple of weeks which really help people better understand the product and help target market to specific cohorts. And it's just that the way we're shifting marketing, the team has done an amazing job really redialing how we approach marketing led by our new CMO, Chris Russo might were going to see more of this and we hope it will help us to continue to manage us over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think from the perspective, Eric, we look at the anticipation of what is arguably the biggest PC of intellectual property in the world that is not seen a movie in many, many years. As you I think you know, the anticipation whether it's North America, wh
componenttext: I think from the perspective, Eric, we look at the anticipation of what is arguably the biggest PC of intellectual property in the world that is not seen a movie in many, many years. As you I think you know, the anticipation whether it's North America, whether it's Europe, whether it's Asia, it's off the charts. I don't think it correlates necessarily to how we think about it. This is a global title. I've been traveling around the world recent and checking and all of our retail in digital channels in the global basis and we're fired up and ready to go. The movie feels like one of the true global launches when you start to speak with consumers around the road, the anticipation levels are high, which I don't think there's a direct correlation to how we would face our revenue from region to region. It's going to big and bigger.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of dilution issue, I'll just remind everyone that the current shares that are being redeemed. We're issuing shares that are counterbalanced by the shares in the hedge transaction that we set up. And so until the actual bond is redeemed fully
componenttext: Yes. In terms of dilution issue, I'll just remind everyone that the current shares that are being redeemed. We're issuing shares that are counterbalanced by the shares in the hedge transaction that we set up. And so until the actual bond is redeemed fully at next summer, the clock then starts to tick on the potential future dilution around those shares. And so the dilution would be approximately 90 days after the bond is fully redeemed. And so there's no dilution this year. We have updated our table on the websites on our IR website to reflect that. The future dilution could occur late next year and we'll be back to you with some of our ideas around how we're going to manage that.
